comments:
[{u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'On an individual plant level yes but it's the total biomass of the area that matters - one redwood tree (for example) absorbs more carbon dioxide than almost anything else but (let's say) it took up a quarter of an acre (as nothing much grows under redwoods) - the plants in a different quarter of an acre may absorb an equal amount of CO2 when put together so you get the same CO2 sequestration from the same area. 
What the author is suggesting doesn't mean you won't get trees it jsut means you'll get them slower - she's basically arguing for allowing succession to kick in - this does have ecological advantages as it'll allow a more complex forest ecosystem to develop (including insect and other creepy crawly life). Their trucks line the roads into this place with wood for sale by truck load.So people have adapted to changes.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543430814000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'123106045', u'id': u'123106351', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'They used to use this place for grazing of cattle intensively about 50 or so years ago. Invasive specie removal may be a necessary task.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543430366000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14139778', u'in_reply_to': u'123105638', u'id': u'123106045', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'userles', u'text': u'Two,s company trees a forest .', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543430087000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13465775', u'id': u'123105832', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ronnewmexico', u'text': u'Well perhaps this is a intended conclusion, I suspect so.....there is really no way to do all those things.Can we eat vegan use less our cars perhaps buy electric ones or hybrids, use less plastic reuseable bags…..yes we can. I'm gone', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543405019000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3788388', u'id': u'123086873', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Jenner', u'text': u'There's a fundamental problem with this article and that's the scarcity of trees, and by extension seed stock, in large parts of the country. Natural regeneration can't happen in areas like the Yorkshire dales and much of the north where trees are few and those that are there are lacking in diversity, both in terms of the species present and genetic diversity. It would take a thousand years for a forest to regenerate in the Pennines without human intervention. Where you have deforestation you also end up with a disproportionate percentage of non native trees as well since gardeners and local government are far more likely to have planted them than any native species, so much of the regeneration would be largely unhelpful.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543396578000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15169780', u'id': u'123080981', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FelixMyIcecream', u'text': u'BQSTART
unmanaged establishment will lead to a thicket of sally and birch crowding out more desirable species
BQEND
That's still in the short term relative to the age of our longest lived Trees . In a natural regeneration eventually the climax species will prevail over the pioneer species without any intervention. The question is whether the purpose of the forest is as a managed resource or a wild place as a natural reservoir for bio-diversity ?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543396518000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'bqstart unmanaged establishment', u'effect': u'a thicket of sally and birch crowding out more desirable species bqend'}], u'author_id': u'15622324', u'in_reply_to': u'123073817', u'id': u'123080933', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ross King', u'text': u'Thank you both for the info. I did not know your lynx was larger. Re wolverines: I can just imagine the newspaper stories when some power couple's Bowser decides to chase one.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543382944000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100459019', u'in_reply_to': u'123072711', u'id': u'123077675', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sadlynot', u'text': u'There are a number of fallacies in this article.First, natural regeneration varies greatly from place to place. If you have it in abundance, the management can be as costly as planting. And if the intention is to end up with quality timber, management is essential.Second, bare rooted whips, if handled properly, usually lead to a successful plantation and seldom lead to significant failure. I agree about the use of tree guards: an expensive and often unsuccessful strategy.The ideal of a natural forest is fine, but sympathetic planting of "the right trees in the right places" is usually the most efficient means of establishing a viable woodland.Where I live, unmanaged establishment will lead to a thicket of sally and birch crowding out more desirable species: we aspire to better.Establishing and managing woodland does not come cheap, but it should be the aim to create value whilst sequestering carbon.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543363260000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'bare rooted whips', u'effect': u'a successful plantation and seldom lead to significant failure'}, {u'cause': None, u'effect': u'significant failure'}, {u'cause': u'unmanaged establishment', u'effect': u'a thicket of sally and birch crowding out more desirable species'}], u'author_id': u'16532365', u'id': u'123073817', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'c0sm0p0lis', u'text': u'What are you on about? Every time anyone challenges mass car dependency someone pipes up to say they live half way up a mountain in snowdonia.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543360601000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15587680', u'in_reply_to': u'122991814', u'id': u'123072784', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'woodworm20', u'text': u'Just saw your comment re. lynx......Wolverines were native to Britain until the 6th millennium b.c. Lynx would definitely hunt them.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543360127000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11064682', u'in_reply_to': u'123036502', u'id': u'123072577', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'Sustainable or not, wood burning is a major source of air pollution in both rural and urban areas. Huge amounts of particulates are emitted.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543355585000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'in_reply_to': u'122994534', u'id': u'123070467', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'This quote from the linked article is nonsense:As England's navy grew, the need for timber began to seriously pick away at the woodland: from an estimated land coverage of 15% in 1086, England's forests and woods had dwindled to just 5.2% by 1905.
The percentages might be ok, but to attribute blame to the navy is wrong. The real cause would have been permanent land clearance for agriculture (consequence of a growing population), not tree felling for ships (felled trees naturally grow again or are replaced by others).', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543355408000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'in_reply_to': u'122992019', u'id': u'123070398', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'Eurasian Lynx are somewhat larger than your species, and are known to feed to a large extent on Roe Deer. Should take quite a few Muntjac as well. Not sure how much they would prey on Red, Sika & Fallow Deer, but to some extent at least.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543354871000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'in_reply_to': u'123036502', u'id': u'123070204', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'Too warm for wolverines here - it's a more northern species. Agree on wolves and lynx though.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543354661000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'in_reply_to': u'122991556', u'id': u'123070128', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'A lot of the 'low biodiversity' of mature woodland can be attributed to the fact that many woods were managed for decades by felling or coppicing, and consequently have few or none of the more diverse features such as large trees, deadwood, natural treefall gaps etc that you would find in a wildwood.
Likewise for younger woods that have arisen by recent colonisation of open ground within the past few decades - simply not enough time to develop those features.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543354543000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'in_reply_to': u'122991281', u'id': u'123070077', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'Perhaps "fighting" climate change is the wrong mind set. Fighting climate change is impossible as we are causing it. The fight is inside every one of us, an inner battle, to realise that we cannot continue to live within the culture and lifestyle we have created in the last couple of centuries or less. There is no "fight" just a giving up of everything that causes harm. Just stop shopping, driving, holidaying, accepting plastics, leaving the heating on, using too much food, sticking to the basics, walk more, eat plainer foods and so on. There is no fight, just an acceptance.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543354205000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'we', u'effect': u'it'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'harm'}], u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'123069974', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'BQSTART
Ultimately the northern forest is expected to cost £500m. And it is manifestly inefficient.
BQEND
This figure strikes me as misleading - I doubt more than a fairly small fraction of this amount is going to be spent on the actual tree planting. Land acquisition will be the major cost, which will be the same whatever method of woodland establishment is used (planting or natural regeneration).', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543354075000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'id': u'123069923', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'I grow several trees in pots and virginia creeper which is great cover for wildlife. Wildflower seeds I throw around and herbs, bees love herbs especially lavender. All this is no use without reducing our growing population of humans and motorways and buildings to house humans.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543353825000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'123069830', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PondDragon', u'text': u'Gorse gets leggy after a number of years and tends to collapse naturally, making gaps for tree saplings to push through. It's not particularly long lived. So non-intervention is a perfectly fine way to regenerate woodland in gorse-dominated areas, although obviously it will take longer than planting, protecting and weeding the saplings. not 1000s of years though - probably more like decades.
On the plus side, both gorse and willow scrub are very diverse habitats and support a lot of other species. So if the objective is primarily habitat restoration, rather than commercial forestry, it's a perfectly sensible approach. This is an excellent article:
Gorse: Woodland in Waiting', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543353754000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4737020', u'in_reply_to': u'123009902', u'id': u'123069804', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Ross King', u'text': u'Your question intrigued me so I investigated. As seems logical, Ireland was heavily forested along with the rest of western Europe. Denudation was entirely due to human agency and was more or less complete by the beginning of the nineteenth century.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543347820000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'human agency', u'effect': u'denudation was and was more or less complete by the beginning of the nineteenth century'}], u'author_id': u'100459019', u'in_reply_to': u'123055705', u'id': u'123067590', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RossCherrington', u'text': u'You can leave it well alone but it wont look like what you want. Old litter is covered by new litter each year until oxygen is no longer available to deeper litter.However I agree we also need a quicker or completely different process obviously, in fact lots of them.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543313880000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'1417810', u'in_reply_to': u'123017049', u'id': u'123043190', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GrumpyOldFool', u'text': u'Our cottage came with a couple of acres of what can be best described as scrubland surrounded by dead trees, and over the last 10 years we've planted over 500 hedgelings (blackthorn, hawthorn, field maple, hazel) and removed all the diseased elms. The hedges are now mature, the blackthorns are self propagating by seeding with sloes and we have to work hard to stop them taking over the open spaces. Acorns propagate easily but do so in places the oak will not live to maturity, and transplanting has a poor survival rate. Willows are profuse but need constant attention (pollarding) to avoid them being damaged by the wind. Rewilding is all very well, but you can't just leave such places to manage themselves.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543303937000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17968071', u'id': u'123037079', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'FelixMyIcecream', u'text': u'BQSTART

Even then you'd most likely get no more than a Restocking Notice."
Quite! The owners of a house near ours had a healthy oak well over a hundred years old removed so they could put a swimming pool in their back garden a few years back. I don't think it was reported and as far as I know they experienced no repercussions.
On the other hand, we had to deal with a tree in our front garden that was the result of previous owners (council tenants!) allowing the hedge to grow out of control. The boom of a skip lorry damaged one of the main branches which was overhanging the entrance to a garage area for the local houses, but the council tree officer would only allow minimal tree surgery because the girth of the trees in our 'roadside hedge' meant they were protected!
To this day we aren't allowed to have them removed and replaced with the proper hedge they should have been all along. How do we just leave things to rewild by themselves? If it were that easy, there'd already be a forest there. Clearly some kind of organized human intervention is necessary, if only to cordon off areas selected for rewilding. Then there's the question of how previous human management of the landscape would affect the rewilding; wouldn't those species already present in the landscape have a massive advantage over the diverse woodland species that we'd like to see, but some of which may not be present because human activity has long ago driven them out? More generally, aren't the examples given of open woodland rather than closed canopy forest also themselves products of human intervention? A 'forest' in medieval times was a royal hunting area, not woodland per se- a meaning that came later. There may have been many trees, but as the article implies, the land was managed and some trees at least were removed. This may be the best method, but it seems a little disingenuous to call it rewilding. Finally, the point about commercial nurseries is a good one, but do they have to be commercial? Couldn't a dedicated nursery or nurseries solve many of these problems? Up in Scotland the replanting of the Caledonian Forest carried out by Trees for Life has its own nurseries.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543269764000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'human activity has long ago driven them out', u'effect': u'some of which may not be present'}], u'author_id': u'11606350', u'id': u'123028325', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GuardianOfTime', u'text': u'After you, old bean.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543269616000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13058127', u'in_reply_to': u'123014676', u'id': u'123028253', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'stevedeeming', u'text': u'I am interested in Richard Mabey's view on this..If I read him right it is a form of rewilding that takes into account tree time rather than human time and things can be left to sort themselves out...which leads to the perceived problem of closed canopy....yes, it might be for a while, but something would fall and allow light through to give glades and other species would grow and understorey would change too. The processes that ensue are the same."
It absolutely does matter - the processes are absolutely not the same. When species move ranges under non human induced conditions it takes a long long time and happens gradually - allowing evolution to occur. When you dump rats on new zealand the species there cannot cope and evolution cannot keep place so you get (in essence) a localised mass extinction (and increasingly a global one)
I'm not sure where you get the idea that species move from one side of the globe to the other all the time from? That has literally never happened at the sort of speed we are talking about - evolution is painfully slow. Species ranges change really really slowly as well.
Let's take homo sapiens - a species that evolved in east africa and spread out across the Eurasian continent (one of the fastest and most wide ranging species expansions of all time - especially for mammals) this took hundreds of thousands of years and happened slowly and in a geographically coordianted way - now we are dumping snakes on islands hundreds, if not thousands of miles away This is causing a mass extinctio event (along with habitat destruction) and to a lesser extent hunting that is greater tahn anything that has happened in 65 million years. Now that sounds hyperbolic but it actually isn't - the current extinction rate is hundreds of times faster than the background rate. 
You would expect to see one amphibian species (in the entire world) go extinct approximately every 1000 years - we are seeing orders of magnitude more than that. In the case of amphibains the primary cause is the introduction of an invasive non native fungus - the chytrid fungus. This fungus evolved in Africa (probably) where it evolved in tandem with the African clawed frog -t his species was then exported around the world (alongside the fungus which didn't ddo that species any real harm as the clawed frog had evolved a defence against it). Unfortunately this fungus is pretty much 100% lethal to almost every other amphibain species so as the african clawed frog has been exported around the world the fungus has gone with it and bang, there go native species. Worryingly a similar (and related fungus) has now been discovered in salamanders in the Americas - in exactly the same way', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543261354000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'this', u'effect': u'a mass extinctio event along with habitat destruction'}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'123023070', u'id': u'123024571', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'uncommodified', u'text': u'It has many benefits beyond climate change. Species is a human classification but they are also an objective reality - just like the sun is still a star regardless of whether humans existed. T rex was a different species to triceratops.
I'm unsure what bad consequences you think there are after removing an invasive species - literally every time it has been done it has allowed native ecosystems to recover, every time', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543260702000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'123023287', u'id': u'123024343', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'We are not epecially like Guam that is true but I'm not sure what difference that makes? Water voles only still exist in the UK because huge efforts have been made to save them. 
Parakeets havent caused any extinctions yet - although dramatically reducing numbers of other species is bad in and of itself - which they will do. 
Australia (a continent sized island) has seen more extinctions than almost anywhere else int he world over the last couple of centuries - caused by invasive species. 
Grey squirrels have nearly driven red squirrels to extinction in the UK - red squirrrels only now remain in part of Scotland and a couple of other places where they have to be protected from greys. 100 years ago, even 50 years ago red squirrels occupied the whole of the UNited Kingdom - now they have been driven back into a small corner - this has been caused by grey squirrels', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543260539000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'huge efforts have been made to save them', u'effect': u'water voles only still exist in the uk'}, {u'cause': u'parakeets', u'effect': u'any extinctions'}, {u'cause': u'invasive species', u'effect': None}, {u'cause': u'grey squirrels', u'effect': u'this'}], u'author_id': u'12031469', u'in_reply_to': u'123023070', u'id': u'123024265', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JonathanHughes', u'text': u'No I'm saying that you cannot justify murdering millions of humans because that is genocide. Chinese,American, Armenian people are all the same species. 
It's being a non native non human species (if that is more accurate) that is important. 
There are many non native species - personally I would (if possible) remove all of them but as that is not feasible we have to focus on the ones that are doing the most damage. Sycamores for example haven't had a huge impact on native species (and there is in fact significant debate over whether sycamores are native) whereas American mink (for example) have nearly wiped out the native water vole (only huge efforts to prevent this has saved the species) in the UK. The grey squirrel has wiped out the red squirrel from pretty much all of its native range in the UK, the American crayfish is, as we speak wiping out native crayfish species and underminging river banks and devastating native insect andfish populations.
To move beyon the Uk for a second - the brown tree snake has wiped out 13 endemic bird species in Guam. Norfolk Island (near New Zealand) has lost 8 endemic bird speces to invasive species and more are in trouble, New Zealand has lost 30+ native species - most of which were either all or to a degree wiped out by invasive species.
lord Howe island alone has lost the lord howe swamphen, the white throated pigeon, the red crowned parakeet, the tasman booby, the tinted thrush, the robust white eye, the Lord Howe Starling, the Lord Howe geryone and the Lord Howe fantail.

description: Rather than replanting a vast northern forest, allow nature to do the job, says author Isabella Tree
og_fields.og:description: Rather than replanting a vast northern forest, allow nature to do the job, says author Isabella Tree
og_fields.og:title: We need to bring back the wildwoods of Britain to fight climate change | Isabella Tree
text:
Earlier this year the government announced plans for a new northern forest. Under the auspices of the Woodland Trust, an area that stretches 120 miles from Hull to Liverpool will be planted with 50 million trees over the next 25 years. In March, the first trees were put in the ground on hills above Bolton, in Greater Manchester, by an “army of planters” composed of local community members, volunteers, funding bodies and MPs.
There is, certainly, an urgent environmental need to get trees back in our landscape. We lost more ancient woods – tens of thousands of them – in the 40 years after the second world war than in the previous 400 years. The UK has only 13% woodland cover, compared with the European average of 37%. Quite apart from being beautiful things, trees – like all vegetation – absorb CO2 from the atmosphere, and the northern forest is intended to help the UK government meet its carbon emissions target by 2050.
Better for biodiversity and the taxpayer would be to allow insects, mammals, the wind and birds to do the tree-planting
But there’s a much more effective way of re-establishing trees in the wider countryside than putting a spade in the ground – and one that has far greater benefits for biodiversity, carbon sequestration and the trees’ health, and that would save us a fortune in financial and environmental costs. And that is natural regeneration – let the trees plant themselves.
The reason this doesn’t happen nowadays is our demonisation of thorny scrub. Hawthorn, blackthorn, dog-rose, gorse and bramble are nature’s barbed wire. These species provide saplings with protection from browsing by deer and rabbits; shelter from the wind; a buffer against drought and excessive rain; and nutrients via mutual mycorrhizal connections underground. Thorny scrub is also one of the most biodiverse habitats – providing a rich source of berries, seeds, nectar, pollen and nuts for small mammals, insects and birds, as well as protection from predators.
But we’ve forgotten about this precious resource in recent times. In the days before plastics and mass manufacture, thorny scrub provided us with charcoal, medicines, dyes, food, fodder, thatching, furniture, gunpowder and tools. Above all, it was valued as a nursery for trees. “The thorn is the mother of the oak” is an ancient forestry saying. Thorny scrub was considered so valuable that a 1768 statute in the New Forest imposed three months’ forced labour and lashes of the whip on anyone found extracting it. Now, however, we consider scrub “wasteland” and eradicate it wherever it appears, and even on nature reserves, volunteers spend weekends“scrub-bashing”.
The modern system of establishing trees relies entirely on humans, and saplings produced in nurseries. Even with a volunteer workforce this is expensive. Ultimately the northern forest is expected to cost £500m. And it is manifestly inefficient. Commercial saplings – bare-root “whips” – are vulnerable, and can easily dry out and die before, or even after, they’re planted. They are not as well connected to the soil as naturally established seedlings, and often lack the appropriate fungal associates. They need to be individually protected by tree guards, almost invariably carbon-intensive polypropylene cylinders tied with plastic ties to treated wooden stakes. Even if the areas to be planted are protected from deer by a perimeter fence, tree guards are poor protection against burrowing rabbits and voles, which cannot be fenced out. Humidity inside the tubes can induce rot and mildews. Using saplings from commercial nurseries also carries a risk of importing disease. Chalara, or ash dieback, was spread into the UK this way.
And anyway, is one enormous plantation what we want for our northern forest? Closed-canopy woodland is remarkably species-poor. Even ancient woodland is not the biodiverse wonderland it is often held to be. Species monitoring in Lady Park Wood in the Forest of Dean and the Mens Nature Reserve in Sussex – considered to be some of our oldest surviving stands of trees – shows a downward trajectory for biodiversity. There may be saproxylic (dead-wood-specialising) fungi and beetles in these densely shaded woods, but there is precious little else. With no sunlight, there’s no birdsong, no thrum of pollinating insects, no wildflowers.
Herein lies the great “forest” misconception. Underpinning the northern forest project is the idea that Britain was originally ubiquitous closed-canopy woodland. Before human impact, it’s said, a squirrel could have run from John o’Groats to Land’s End on the tops of trees. Dense forest tends to be the state we aspire to when aiming for nature restoration. But this is the stuff of fairytales. Many of our shrubs and trees – including hazel, wild apple, wild pear, wild cherry, rowan, dogwood, common privet, Scots pine and oak (that quintessentially English tree) – are light-demanding species that cannot regenerate in closed-canopy conditions. They point to a much more open landscape – a wood-pasture system driven by free-roaming herds of grazing and browsing animals, where trees regenerated out in the open, within thorny scrub. This is the landscape described by Oliver Rackham, our late, great woodland expert, as the “wildwood”. It is the landscape of the New Forest and all the other hunting forests of medieval England – a dynamic mosaic of gigantic open-grown trees and groves of all species and ages, grazing “lawns”, water meadows and thorny scrub. Paradise for wildlife.
Far better for biodiversity and the taxpayer would be to allow small mammals, the wind and birds to do the tree planting for us. A single jay can plant 7,500 acorns in four weeks. Carrying these highly calorific oak nuts in its gullet, six at a time, the jay flies away to bury them a commodious distance from the parent oak tree, often in, or near, protective thorny scrub, as a store for feeding itself through the winter and its young in spring. The acorns that are not recovered by the jay end up developing into saplings.
Rewilding – enabling natural processes to function as they are meant to – allows the jay and all the other seed dispersers to do their job. But this is not something that organisations like the Woodland Trust have embraced with any real enthusiasm. Their fundraising model depends on grant aid, and the messy, competitive, variable responses of nature do not fit within a grant system that requires precise costs, targets and predictability. The appeal of physically digging a hole and planting a tree is also a powerful way of recruiting donors and volunteers. If charities simply left it to nature, a major means of forging those relationships would vanish.
It’s encouraging that in June the government appointed its first “tree champion”, William Worsley, the former president of the Country Landowners Association. As well as protecting existing trees he will spearhead the planting of millions of new ones. But I urge him to rethink how we do this – and to consider areas where we could return to the richer forest systems of old, to the wildwood, a landscape naturally imbued with spirit of place, where the thorn can once again be the “mother of the oak”.
• Isabella Tree is the author of Wilding: The Return of Nature to a British Farm

description: Material that said humans were warming the planet was taken down last year for an ‘update’
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Material that said humans were warming the planet was taken down last year for an ‘update’
og_fields.og:title: 'It's a ghost page': EPA site's climate change section may be gone for good
text:
More than a year after the US Environmental Protection Agency took down information on climate change from its website for an “update”, it now seems uncertain whether it will ever reappear.
In April last year, the EPA replaced its online climate change section with a holding page that said the content was being updated to “reflect the agency’s new direction under President Donald Trump”.
Information previously found at epa.gov/climatechange made it clear that human activity was warming the planet, resulting in harm to Americans’ health as well as crucial ecosystems on which humans depend.
The “update” page has now given way to a page that simply states: “We want to help you find what you are looking for.” Below, there are links to search other areas of the EPA website, as well as to an archived “snapshot” of the site from the day before Trump became president in January 2017. The switch was observed by the Environmental Data & Governance Initiative, which tracks changes in government websites.
“It’s an embarrassment. It is a ghost page,” said Judith Enck, who was EPA regional administrator during Barack Obama’s presidency. “It’s a bit like Amazon not allowing the public to order books via its website – it’s that fundamental. There’s no other issue at the EPA more important than climate change; it affects air, water, health and whether large parts of the world will survive.”
Scott Pruitt, a climate change skeptic who was Trump’s pick as EPA administrator until he resigned in July amid a long-running ethics scandal, repeatedly questioned basic scientific understanding of climate change while he headed the agency, such as whether carbon dioxide is a primary driver of planetary warming.
The EPA under the Trump administration has attempted to roll back all key measures designed to address climate change, such as limits on pollution from coal plants, rules to prevent methane emissions from oil and gas drilling and tighter fuel efficiency standards for cars. Andrew Wheeler, a former coal lobbyist who is now acting EPA administrator, has said “federal regulations are not necessary to drive greenhouse gas reductions”.
A senior EPA official, who asked not to be named, said: “Wheeler has been somewhat meticulously going through the mess Pruitt left behind and I think is finally getting to the place of making some decisions on stuff.” The official added: “I’ve been surprised that we are still even talking about climate change and that there are still people nominally assigned to that beat in the air office.”
Enck said that EPA career staff are “frustrated” and “ashamed” about the new stance on climate change and urged her former colleagues to speak out.
The administration also began taking the ax to climate change language across other government websites in the spring of 2017.
“The EPA website is used by decision and policy makers, not just for high school student assignments,” she said. “The lack of timely, accurate information is part of a much deeper problem that the agency is on the sidelines of the most urgent environment issue of our time.”
The EPA was contacted for comment.

https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/Features/GlobalWarming/page2.php', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541488170000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16007648', u'in_reply_to': u'122216244', u'id': u'122218472', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Fred1', u'text': u'Oh dear.
A former treasurer and deputy prime minister of Australia thinks that taxes are used to pay for stuff.
So at no stage when Wayne Swan was setting tax rates did he understand why he was doing it?
That's like a surgeon randomly chopping away at a person's body without any idea of what is causing the pain. Of course the difference between the surgeon and a treasurer is the former is working off science whereas the latter is working off whichever economic/political doctrine he's chosen to follow. The treasurer has more in common with a witch doctor.
A country like Australia, which has its own currency, does not raise revenue through taxation. That's not what taxes are for. Taxes have two purposes, Wayne Swan:
a) to remove money from the economy so as to manage inflation; andb) to manage behaviour e.g. reducing smoking or, relevantly, reducing carbon emissions. 
I agree with Wayne Swan that governments need to spend money, for example, to tackle earthquakes.. But governments do not need to fund that through taxation. They simply need to spend money since if they have their own currency then they are the sole source of said currency. 
Other than our incessant greed, politicians total ignorance about how government finances work is the single biggest obstacle to tackling climate change. Particularly since it results in the ludicrous situation where governments are more concerned about deficits than climate change.
Here's a stat I never get tired of quoting - what some countries spent in WW2 dollars:
1. U.S : $296 billion (roughly $4,104 billion dollars today)2. Germany : $272 billion3. Britain : $120 billion4. Soviet Union : $192 billion5. Italy : $94 billion6. Japan : $56 billion.
While the US was spending all of that money on war it spent the equivalent of about $25b on the Marshall Project bringing the finest minds together to split the atom. 
After WW2 the US spent about $ 110b on the Marshall Plan because of a fear of communism taking over Europe and another $109b on the Apollo mission.
If we want to tackle climate change we need this level of spending. Sure, this level of spending will result in governments utilising more resources in the economy (which in reality is the only restriction on government spending) and so this would then lead to reductions in private expenditure and possibly a decline in new iPhones being released every year. I'm not saying there's such a thing as a free lunch. 
Actually I am - over to the hippies at Forbes magazine
https://www.forbes.com/sites/johntharvey/2015/11/06/yes-there-is-a-free-lunch/#37d33aa35a6d

between 1.5c and 4.5c? what an accurate answer !! 
wow. just imagine a rocket scientist launching a satellite to the moon..
"it'll be in orbit 30,000km above the moon, give or take 15,000km" . 
such accurate science, climate science.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541484399000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'122185146', u'id': u'122217888', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'nottrue', u'text': u'There are many more issues than climate change for sure but I think you miss something important. A significant %age of CO2 remains in the atmosphere for many millennia and that %age increases as we continue dumping. Currently the amount of GHGs in the atmosphere if it remained would produce a 2C+ world. The latest IPCC report says at that temperature a tipping point would likely be reached with a significant amount of the tundra melting and releasing more CO2.
So climate change is permanent and we haven't yet experienced what we have already done. Hence it is imperative to stop CO2 production as soon as possible in order to limit future damage. Like a freight train or ocean liner it cannot be stopped quickly.
Renewables are needed to replace coal, gas and then petrol by enabling EVs. We then need to find alternatives to produce steel, cement and fertilisers before we can relax.
Most of the other problems you mention are reversible if we do not procrastinate too long and given the will to do so. But there is no reason why they cannot be tackled in parallel.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541484271000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12655847', u'in_reply_to': u'122217636', u'id': u'122217866', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our

For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541484134000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'122217116', u'id': u'122217843', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JohnArmour', u'text': u'You're getting yourself into a real muddle YellowJoss, confusing the Commonwealth "living beyond its means" with references to spending and declining tax revenues, and households "living beyond their means" with references to household debt.

The paradox is that the the only way to disarm that household debt bomb is for the Commonwealth to itself go further into "debt".
To understand that you need to have a look at some of the links that have been posted.
BTW, about the only thing Keating had to say on Asia that's worth remembering is that we should "seek our security within Asia, not from it".', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541484016000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12469905', u'in_reply_to': u'122216028', u'id': u'122217831', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'a) 0.8c of warming - first you are ignoring the error ranges, second, you nor anybody else knows whether the earth was in equilibrium at the start of the industrial revolution. second, you have no way of knowing what the variability of the climate had done at the start state (industrialisation) - to answer whether the 0.8c of warming recorded (+ or - 0.25) is from anthropogenic or other causes
b) while paleoclimate struggles to understand in detail the history of the Earth's climate, its pretty evident from the latest Pages2K report 2015 that right now things arent much different to how they were back 1500 years anyway!

We are not talking here about GHG emissions, but about nuclear waste and to ignore or deny such waste hardly constitutes a respect for the truth.
BQEND
Nuclear waste is managed. It is not willfully dumped into the environment. Spent nuclear fuel straight out of a reactor is extremely hazardous, but it is safely managed. Show me credible evidence of a single fatality anywhere in the last 50 years due to the management of spent nuclear fuel. I have not been able to find one. In contrast oil and gas pipeline accidents in the US alone have caused over 500 fatalities since the 1980s. There is simply no comparison. And that is the truth.
BQSTART
Japanese and international health authorities would dispute your claims about adverse health effects
BQEND
Where? You are making stuff up. Read the UNSCEAR or WHO reports. They are freely available. Here's the 2013 UNSCEAR report. There is a 2016 update, but the basic findings are unaltered. UNSCEAR operates under the auspices of the United Nations Environment Program as does the IPCC. Like the IPCC, it's findings represent consensus science.
BQSTART
But if you want to use renewable energy perhaps you could tell us how many accidents or deaths it has caused.
BQEND
A lot more than nuclear power. The Banqiao Dam Disaster caused the deaths of 171,000 people and made 11 million homeless. It is by far the worst industrial accident ever by a very large margin. Could there be a repeat? Yes there could. The Mosal Dam in Iraq is at risk of failure. Such an event would be catastrophic:
The main scenario analysed in this study, where the dam is 26% destroyed, the level of the lake is at its maximum value of 330m, and most of the lake’s water is allowed to flow out fast, results in a very high wave of water (in places 25m high, mean height around 12m) arriving at Mosul city after 1h40min. The capital Baghdad is reached after about 3.5 days with a max water height of 8m and a mean of around 2m. The simulations suggest that in the above scenario a total of more than 6 million people (close to one sixth of the country’s population) will be affected by floodwaters, with two million of them facing water of more than 2m. Water heights of more than 10m would inundate an area with 270 000 people, most of them in Mosul city and its surroundings, whose lives, houses and infrastructure would risk complete destruction.
No credible nuclear power accident could possibly come anywhere near this. So why aren't you anti-nukes campaigning against big dams? When all is said and done, nothing is absolutely 100% safe and never can be. Yes, really. Most people mistakenly think it is just a question of cutting back CO2 emissions, and then it will be business as usual. They are wrong.
The human race has severely disrupted the planet's ability to regulate itself - not just by pumping vast quantities of CO2 into the air, but by damaging all of the natural mechanisms the planet uses to regulate its temperature and atmosphere.
We have stripped the globe of more than 50% of its forests, we have over fished most of the oceans, we have destroyed thousands of species of animal and plant life, we have fatally wounded most of the coral reefs, we have polluted the seas with plastic, choking and poisoning the fish, we have........................... need I go on?
No, we need to stop tinkering around the edges and face up to the reality - and that is that most of us are going to experience very very severe climate and economic disruption within the next few decades regardless of what we do. Yes, regardless.
The latest IPCC report is still far too conservative, but even that is still telling us that it is very very very serious indeed, that we are, as they say, in 'deep s**t'.
We have to change our ways as a human race - stopping all of the damaging and polluting behaviour, and we have to prepare to live in a much hotter world in the only regions that will support life near the two poles. The equatorial regions will be probably uninhabitable by the end of the century.
A lot of scientists know this, but are not being heard. They know that we have to face up to the reality if we are to save the lives of billions of people.', u'recommendation_count': u'13', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541481580000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12044727', u'id': u'122217461', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'David Stewart', u'text': u'Reducing the deductions companies can claim is should be the main focus. * Fiscal Ledger No. 1: Total of Currency Issued - $ x.* Fiscal Ledger No. 2: Total of Currency Cancelled by Taxation - $ x.

The former is a much more direct route to a solution than the latter.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541478630000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12720428', u'in_reply_to': u'122216474', u'id': u'122217046', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bearmuchly', u'text': u'Sorry Wayne, but getting large corporates to pay taxes is far too simplistic ......it is certainly required, but it is addressing a symptom rather than the disease itself.
What needs to happen is the dismantling of corporate global entitiesby limiting their size and the only way to do that (other than via lessthan desirable means) is to regulate corporate ownership structuresassiduously, thereby limiting their political power and influence......this is also the only way we will seriously tackle our most existentialthreats incl. climate change, destruction of bio diversity and a moreequitable wealth distribution.
Now don't get me wrong, I am a strong supporter of capitalism BUTcapitalism at a "human scale" (apologies to EF Schumacher)......businesses at the local and regional levels are desirable, corporationsat the national level, may be OK, especially when publically owned.....businesses that dominate national markets and businesses thatare multinational are the problem......they distort markets, createcartels, are monopolistic, dominate the political process and threatendemocracy. No corporate entity NEEDS to be the size of the largest2000 to 3000 on the globe today, no corporate entity should beable to dictate national (and international) policy, no corporate entity should own another entity, no financier should own some or all of another entity.

I guess my point is that, sure, they need to get their houses in order and takeresponsibility (economically, Indonesia is certainly doing so) but victim blamingactively undermines a remedial process whereas offers of support, in termsof capital, expertise and investment, coupled with open dialogue and the encouragement of trade, technology transfers, people movements incl. tourism,students, cultural exchanges etc. MUST be the way of the future to build a constructive global/multilateral and interactive process.......it is certainly theonly way we will remediate/ lessen the ecological carnage we are wreaking......victim blaming creates jingoism, closed borders and minds and even greaterpotential catastrophes......history has taught us that !', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541477095000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the poor levels of governance'}], u'author_id': u'14433057', u'in_reply_to': u'122216474', u'id': u'122216856', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'JimDandelion', u'text': u'You don't need to be smart to understand what MMT is. But as well as a federal ICAC (NSW-type, not Victorian-type), we need a ban on private "donations" to politicians and their parties (perhaps with minor exceptions for parties that don't meet a minimum % of the vote), more viable public funding of politicians and parties, and strict rules for lobbyists.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541470879000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'10810511', u'in_reply_to': u'122183695', u'id': u'122215817', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'R_Ambrose_Raven', u'text': u'Remind then Gillard Labor Resources and Energy Minister and now senior APPEA (Petroleum Producer’s and Exporter’s Association) executive Martin Ferguson of that.
Another one of many Big Mining tax concessions - specifically for the LNG industry - was the October ’10 decision by Ferguson to allow its MRRT to be assessed on value at the point it is mined instead of at the point where it leaves the country after being frozen into LNG. Wholesale taxing in effect, since the value of the input - coal-seam methane gas - is much less than the value of the output - liquid natural gas. Its means of course considerably less tax revenue.
MRRT Policy Transition Group was co-chaired by Martin Ferguson and former BHP Billiton chairman Don Argus. It would seem unlikely that Martin Ferguson would have been given a senior APPEA executive role were he seen as hostile to transnational interests.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541476510000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12554246', u'id': u'122216776', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DeepNorthDave', u'text': u'We are not talking here about GHG emissions, but about nuclear waste and to ignore or deny such waste hardly constitutes a respect for the truth. But if you want to use renewable energy perhaps you could tell us how many accidents or deaths it has caused.Private for profit corporations may be obliged to clean up and rehabilitate the sight (so do coal miners but there are thousands of un-remediated mine sites in Qld alone) and after 40 years Three Mile Is. has not been cleaned up, nor has Chernoble after 32 years and nor has Fukashima. Meanwhile Sellafield/Windscale has by the operators own admission discharged unknown amount of toxic waste into the Irish Sea.Here in Australia at Lucas Heights, all they've done is stacked the waste in 44 gal drums down the end of the back paddock. Not my idea of "managing". Regarding "banging on about renewables"
The tragedy of global warming, is we are the first generation that knows how to make energy sustainably.
In Pennsylvania during the early days of the US there were furnaces and forges powered by charcoal used to make the iron which built the East.
They’d cut down a lot of trees and burn them under ground with low oxygen to make charcoal. When Europeans first came to N America they said that a squirrel could go up a tree on the East Coast and stay in trees without touching ground all the way to the Mississippi River.
They cut down so many of these trees that a crisis developed and the Pennsylvania Government had to step in and tell people they couldn’t cut trees down on their own property. (think about that if you are against government intervention and suspicious of science ‘cause there are crises coming that will require much government intervention).
We were burning our way through whale oil when the discovery of fossil fuels saved the whales, and now we’re burning fossil fuels one million times faster than nature replenishes them which is heating the planet dangerously fast.
We know now how to farm energy from the wind, Sun, waves, geothermal, etc, etc. The question is, Will we use that knowledge or suffer the consequences?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541474920000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122216474', u'id': u'122216509', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fencedweller', u'text': u'Give us a break Wayne. Stop the SUV/ Ute growth in it's tracks with similar taxes.. Give tax incentives to cars under 1 tonne in weight with lowest fuel consumption. Give rebates on bicycles etc etc. Carrot and stick always work well.Stop building monster homes and 2windowless apartments that need air conditioning 9 months of the year.It's all too hard for most. Just bang on about renewables and all will be well in the garden.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541474663000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12290642', u'id': u'122216474', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'YellowJoss', u'text': u'BQSTART

Then we have more reality from the latest Lowy Institute Poll - Climate Change and Energy..59% of respondents supported the statement:“climate change is a serious and pressing problem. We should begin taking steps now even if this involves significant costs.”84% of respondents support the statement: “the government should focus on renewables, even if this means we may need to invest more in infrastructure to make the system more reliable”https://lowyinstitutepoll.lowyinstitute.org/climate-change-and-energy/', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541474309000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16020012', u'in_reply_to': u'122215811', u'id': u'122216428', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, ...]
description: Less fiscal revenue means less money for vital infrastructure and less money to prepare for the effects of natural disasters
og_fields.og:description: Less fiscal revenue means less money for vital infrastructure and less money to prepare for the effects of natural disasters
og_fields.og:title: For us to tackle climate change, companies need to pay their tax | Wayne Swan
text:
It’s been a year of natural disasters. After Irma, Maria, Harvey, hurricane Florence left a devastating landscape in the Caribbean. Extreme temperatures across the northern hemisphere have caused devastating fires from Europe to the US. Dozens have been killed in the Philippines after typhoon Mangkhut triggered landslides.
And the worst consequences of climate change are yet to come.
It is a huge challenge for rich countries and for developing nations, a sisyphean task: how to collect enough revenue to respond to major catastrophes, while at the same time trying to lift billions of people out of poverty?
Look at Indonesia. Disasters are a familiar tragedy in the world’s fourth most populous nation, with its thousands of islands across hundreds of miles of ocean. This should make disaster risk planning crucial. It is not the case, as the latest earthquake and tsunami showed. Reports revealed that parts of the tsunami alert system didn’t work. In some areas, there were no sirens at all. The death toll is still climbing.
Indonesia is the largest economy in south-east Asia and is projected to become the fourth largest economy in the world by 2050, behind China, the US and the EU. However, this prediction depends on its capacity to secure sufficient public revenue. It is the only way to finance, for example, the preparation and maintenance of earthquake-resistant buildings and infrastructure and warning systems.
With big companies paying less and less taxes, most governments have the same answer: austerity
Natural disasters tend to worsen economic inequality in already critical situations, such as that in Indonesia. While many have been lifted out of poverty in the past two decades, the gap between the rich and the poor has grown faster than in any other south-east Asian country. The government now has an ambitious medium term strategy to deal with wide wage disparities and dramatically unequal access to infrastructure, education and health services.
Addressing all these challenges requires revenue.
At an average of 17.6% of GDP, tax collection in the Asia-Pacific region is among the lowest in the world, a level regarded by experts as totally insufficient to achieve sustainable development goals. And with big companies paying less and less taxes, most governments have the same answer: austerity.
In the past decade, the average corporate tax rate in the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (Asean) region has fallen from 30 to 22%, reflecting global trends. While these lower tax rates may attract higher levels of foreign investment, they come at a very high price: less fiscal revenues means less money to construct vital public services and infrastructure, not to mention less money to prepare for the effects of natural disasters.
The only winners in this race to the bottom are multinationals, which end up paying almost no taxes. Vito Tanzi, the former head of the IMF’s Tax Policy Division, has branded such tax-avoiding companies “fiscal termites” for eating away the foundations of tax systems around the world. In his recent book, Termites of the State, Tanzi acknowledges that while no fiscal house is fully insulated from these tax pests, developing countries – especially those with mineral resources – are particularly vulnerable.
Developing economies such as Indonesia rely heavily on corporate income tax bases. The IMF reports that the revenue lost from tax evasion in developing countries is 1.3 times larger, as a share of GDP, than it is in advanced economies.
It’s a tough fight that involves tackling power elites, overcoming deep institutional resistance, pursuing inclusive forms of growth, eliminating unacceptable levels of poverty and building quality health and education systems for all.
But the fight back is underway.
The global debate about the tax dodging behaviour of unscrupulous multinationals is beginning to pay dividends. Civil society campaigning has led to the creation of a template for country by country reporting which could eventually expose the scale of tax avoidance in the region. The Independent Commission for the Reform of International Corporate Taxation (ICRICT), of which I am a member, is putting forward a bold agenda of international tax rules from a perspective of global public interest rather than advancing national corporate interest.
In the last decade Indonesia has made great progress towards its sustainable development goals. What a tragedy it would be therefore if this emerging Asia-Pacific middle class fails to emerge because multinational companies continue to get away with dodging tax and ransacking these nations of their wealth.
• Wayne Swan is the former treasurer and deputy prime minister of Australia and a member of the Independent Commission for the Reform of International Corporate Taxation (ICRICT)

article_tags: [US midterms 2018, Trump-Russia investigation, US immigration, Business, US economy, US news, US healthcare, Climate change, US politics]
authors: [Jon Swaine, Amanda Holpuch, Dominic Rushe, Oliver Milman, Adam Gabbatt]
description: The elections have changed the political landscape and will affect the Mueller investigation, the border wall, the economy, healthcare, climate change and redistricting
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: The elections have changed the political landscape and will affect the Mueller investigation, the border wall, the economy, healthcare, climate change and redistricting
og_fields.og:title: What do midterms mean for … climate change, the economy and other issues?
text:
Democrats in the House of Representatives are likely to reopen an intelligence committee investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 election – and begin assisting the criminal inquiry on the same subject by the special counsel Robert Mueller.
Devin Nunes, the committee’s outgoing Republican chairman and a Trump ally, obstructed efforts by Democrats to investigate possible collusion with Russia by Trump’s campaign team, and closed the investigation with leads left unexplored.
Nunes also declined to share information with Mueller.
But Adam Schiff, Nunes’s likely Democratic replacement, has promised to resume the committee’s inquiries and pursue new avenues such as the Trump Organization’s business links to Russia.
The extension of the Republican majority in the Senate, however, may embolden Trump to nominate a harder-line replacement for the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, fired the day after the election, in order to get rid of Mueller and shut down the special counsel’s investigation. If that happens, expect some Democrats to propose rehiring Mueller as an independent counsel to continue his investigation on behalf of the House. Jon Swaine
Now that Democrats have the House, President Trump’s dream of a “big, beautiful wall” will be all the more elusive.
Before the midterms, the outgoing House speaker, Paul Ryan, promised there would be a “big fight” over the border wall immediately after the election. The Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, said this was still the plan on Wednesday morning, but Republicans now go into that fight against an emboldened Democratic party.
By 8 December, Congress must reach a deal on Department of Homeland Security funding, including the wall – a narrow window for Republicans to secure significant wall funding before Democrats take control of the House in January.
House Democrats have also said they will try to restore protections for Dreamers, undocumented immigrants who arrived in the US as children. Voters on both sides of the aisle have expressed broad support for creating a pathway to citizenship for this population and the Trump administration has used them as a bargaining chip since revoking their protections in 2017. Amanda Holpuch
Unless Trump gets re-elected in 2020, it now looks certain his massive tax bill will be his last. That $1.5tn giveaway, Trump’s largest congressional achievement, mainly benefited the very wealthy and corporations and has polled badly with voters, so badly that Republicans barely mentioned it in the run-up to the midterms. He has since promised another tax cut aimed at the middle class.
Now, with Democrats in control of the House, any legislation will be hard to pass.
There are areas of common ground – Trump counselor Kellyanne Conway has already mentioned infrastructure – but given the partisan divide in Washington, striking a deal is going to be difficult.
The picture on trade also becomes more complex as the president’s powers are curtailed. Politicians in China, Europe, Canada, Mexico and elsewhere will all be watching to see how his defeat will affect the trade disputes he has fueled.
Trump can still use executive orders to force through change but the president’s chances of passing meaningful legislation were hobbled on Tuesday. Now he will be buffeted by the larger, outside forces that will decide the US’s economic forces – forces that are beyond his control. Dominic Rushe
Republican efforts to dismantle the Affordable Care Act (ACA) at a national level are almost guaranteed to halt now that the House is in the hands of the Democrats.
At the state level, Democratic governors-elect in Kansas, Maine and Wisconsin could expand ACA protections that Republican state leaders rejected. And in Idaho, Nebraska and Utah citizens voted to expand access to free or low-cost health coverage to the poor through Medicaid.
Before the election, Nancy Pelosi, who is expected to return to her former role as House speaker, said a legislative priority would be lowering pharmaceutical drug costs – an issue that could have bipartisan support.
And reproductive rights groups have called last night’s results a victory. Federal efforts to limit women’s reproductive rights will be challenged with Democrats in control of the House. And in Michigan, Kansas and New Mexico, the three governors-elect have a record for defending women’s reproductive rights. Amanda Holpuch
Attempts to ramp up action to address climate change faltered, most notably in Washington state where voters rejected a proposal to implement a price on carbon pollution. The plan, which was vigorously opposed by oil and gas interests including BP, would have placed a $15 fee on each ton of CO2 and potentially acted as a springboard for other states to do likewise.
Washington state voters have now rejected carbon pricing on three separate occasions, raising doubts as to whether the concept, backed by many economists as the best way to drive down emissions and avoid disastrous climate change, will gain traction in the US.
Elsewhere, a ballot proposal to require that Arizona get half of its electricity from renewable sources like solar and wind was rejected by voters in the state. In Colorado, the fossil fuel industry spent $40m to successfully fend off an attempt to impose a half-mile buffer between drilling operations and people’s homes. In Florida, however, voters backed a measure to ban oil and gas drilling in state waters. Oliver Milman
Democrats picked up seven governor’s seats by early Wednesday.
The governor races are particularly important because of a once-in-a-decade redistricting process due to begin in 2021. States will be required to redraw congressional districts to make sure each one represents the same number of residents.
That’s where gerrymandering – the process where a party draws often oddly shaped districts to best maximize their voters – can occur.
State legislatures do the redrawing, but it is the state’s governor who has the ability to sign or veto the new congressional map in their state. That means a Democrat governor elected on Tuesday to a four-year term would have the power to prevent Republicans – who have become experts at gerrymandering, most notably in Pennsylvania – from redrawing districts in a way which would benefit them in upcoming elections to the House of Representatives.
Florida was seen as particularly important as the state is expected to gain two congressional seats after the 2020 census. That’s down to a long-term population shift away from the north-east and midwest towards states like Florida and Texas. Unfortunately for Democrats, Andrew Gillum lost on Tuesday. Adam Gabbatt

Photograph: Nick Lyon/BBC NHU', u'representativeOfPage': u'true', u'url': u'https://i.guim.co.uk/img/media/a789fbdef2572ba9b0e0eb1fe68e742ab5830480/0_101_4268_2561/master/4268.jpg?width=700&quality=85&auto=format&fit=max&s=7cff773242b73295c92c0b61e51ae747', u'height': u'2561', u'width': u'4268'}}]
article_tags: [David Attenborough, BBC, Media, Television, Climate change, Environment, Nuclear power, Energy, Endangered species]
description: Letters: Readers take Attenborough to task for ignoring the human impact on the natural world
og_fields.og:description: Letters: Readers take Attenborough to task for ignoring the human impact on the natural world
og_fields.og:title: David Attenborough, television and environmental destruction | Letters
text:
I strongly agree with George’s Monbiot’s comments regarding David Attenborough’s latest BBC series, Dynasties (Attenborough has betrayed the living world that he loves, 7 November). Why have most of his wonderful programmes been blind to the tsunami of environmental destruction we have unleashed? Some years ago I confronted Alastair Fothergill, series producer of many of Attenborough’s programmes, at a public meeting: “The Earth is in distress: why do you ignore human impacts?” His response: “Our audience does not want to be disturbed.” What about the mess that future generations will be left with? 
In the 1980s I worked at Channel 4 for Fragile Earth, which broadcast some 20 environmental documentaries a year. But as soon as Michael Grade took over as CEO in 1988, he sacked the commissioning editor – advertisers did not like disturbing programmes. And so the global devastation continues largely unreported in TV documentaries.
British TV has also systematically deprived us of information about solutions to the world’s environmental problems. In some countries, major new green industries are flourishing, but viewers in Britain are being left uninformed. We need well-presented programmes helping us to make the right decisions – as consumers, as parents and as voters. Herbert GirardetAuthor and consultant; co-founder, World Future Council
• If David Attenborough is unwilling or unable to offer potential solutions to the world’s environmental crisis, perhaps the Guardian should invite those who may have solutions to offer these in a series of features with global mass-media and social-media partners. Contributors could include people who understand that population can be lowered and welfare improved by global development based on justice and greater power for women: there are many examples of this which expose the intellectual poverty of neo-Malthusians.
It could include the ideas of economists who reject conventional “growth” as the only way forward. It might tap into the “feasible utopia” ideas of red-green media and thinktanks plus the work of academics who lead the search for sustainability. NGOs and unions could have a role, and there would be space for scientists – but not the Tomorrow’s World types who promised cosy technological fixes for all our problems, passifying a bedazzled public. We must tap into the mass of talented but largely unheard folk who have ideas that begin with the understanding that “another world is possible”.Trevor PhillipsNorwich
• The BBC has been guilty of ignoring or dumbing down important information about climate for a long time. Many other organisations that should know better are also guilty of not shouting loud enough about the consequences of global warming: there has been consistent fear among NGOs that frightening people would have adverse effects. They are all complicit in this cover-up.Maureen EvershedDorridge, West Midlands
• I couldn’t agree more with George Monbiot. We are not children; we do not need to be protected from the truth because it may make us uncomfortable. Our planet is on the cusp of a downward spiral leading to monumental disaster unless we all do something very quickly. And yet the BBC appears to be more interested in audience numbers, still determined to make safe, appealing programmes with David Attenborough at the helm. He is in an almost unique position to make a powerful statement about the remaining wonders, which still exist, but will most certainly disappear in the not too distant future.
And with their disappearance our own species will surely not survive. My generation, and David Attenborough, will be long gone when what’s left of the Earth’s future population will be struggling to stay alive on a very bleak, barren and silent planet. Will they look back and be glad that we were entertained?Carol KnightTisbury, Wiltshire
• I sympathise with the concern that George Monbiot expresses. I think there is a problem that people are liable to be put off by all the warnings of the disastrous consequences. It is very difficult to tread the right line between very bad predictions and reassuring us that something can be done. Avoiding single-use plastics is something people can easily aim for and feel that they are preventing a whale from being killed by plastic. I felt sad to see the recent pictures of all the plastic that one whale had ingested. Then I thought of all the creatures that will never be born because of climate change, and that is even more sad.Janet PoliakoffNottingham
• Your excellent article reporting the devastating effects of humans on other animals illustrates how important it is to avoid further increasing our environmental footprint (Annihilation of wildlife a threat to civilisation, scientists warn, 30 October). A policy promoted by the Guardian, and supported by its readers, requires a huge increase in our environmental footprint: reducing greenhouse gas emissions by replacing fossil fuels with renewable energy.
For example, the late David MacKay showed that in order to meet UK energy needs, solar, wind and biomass “farms’ would need to occupy 5%, 10% and 75 % of our available land area, respectively. The required offshore wind turbines would occupy an area equivalent to a 13km thick strip around the entire UK shore. Wave machines would need to stretch across the entire 500km Atlantic coastline.
Can we reduce greenhouse gas emission without increasing our footprint on this planet? Yes, by exploiting the densest form of energy: nuclear. Although feared by the public, nuclear has the best safety record of all forms of energy, and is far safer than fossil fuel. Even the most catastrophic nuclear accidents, such as the ones at Chernobyl and Fukushima, eventually caused very few deaths (43 after Chernobyl and none at Fukushima).If we want to protect other species from humans and avoid catastrophic climate change, we need to shift our focus from renewables and expand nuclear energy. Prof Anton van der MerweSir William Dunn School of Pathology, University of Oxford

article_tags: [Insects, Reproduction, Biology, Climate change, Climate change, Animals, Environment, World news, Science]
description: Study of beetles could explain global decline – and also be a warning to humankind
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Study of beetles could explain global decline – and also be a warning to humankind
og_fields.og:title: Heatwaves can 'wipe out' male insect fertility
text:
Heatwaves severely damage the fertility of male beetles and consecutive hot spells leave them virtually sterilised, according to research.
Global warming is making heatwaves more common and wildlife is being annihilated, and the study may reveal a way in which these two trends are linked. The scientists behind the findings said there could also be some relevance for humans: the sperm counts of western men have halved in the last 40 years.
Researchers studied beetles because their 400,000 species represent about a quarter of all known species. Insect populations are plunging worldwide as temperatures rise, falling by about 80% in 30 years in Puerto Rico’s rainforest and by 75% in German nature reserves.
Insects are such an integral part of life, as pollinators and prey, that scientists say their decline could lead to “ecological Armageddon”. Little is known about the precise causes of the decline, though climate change, habitat destruction and global use of pesticides are considered probable factors.
The research, published in the Nature Communications journal, found that exposing beetles to a five-day heatwave in the laboratory reduced sperm production by three-quarters; females were unaffected.
“Beetles are thought to constitute a quarter of biodiversity, so these results are very important for understanding how species react to climate change,” said Kris Sales, at the University of East Anglia, who led the work.
Other research has shown that heat can damage male reproduction in humans as well as cows, sheep and other mammals.
“There could be relevance for human fertility,” said Prof Matt Gage, co-leader of the UEA research group. “The paradox is that one of the reasons the climate is warming up and we are having more heatwaves is there are too many humans. So maybe this is a leveller.”
Stuart Wigby, of the University of Oxford, who was not involved in the study, said: “Given what we already know about the generality of the sensitivity of sperm to heat, there is every reason to expect that similar effects would be seen in other insects and also in mammals including humans.”
The red flour beetle used in the experiments is a tropical species that thrives at 35C. When exposed to temperatures of 5C and 7C higher, male fertility plummeted. While these were high temperatures, 90 countries had experienced them in recent years, said Gage.
After being exposed to a heatwave, the number of offspring produced by males fell by half. Even more worryingly, harmful effects were inherited by the males they produced – their lives were 20% shorter and they in turn produced fewer offspring.
The most extreme impact was in male beetles exposed to two heatwaves 10 days apart – their offspring production fell by 99%. “It kind of wipes them out,” Gage said.
Sales added: “Insects in nature are likely to experience multiple heatwave events, which could become a problem for population productivity if male reproduction cannot adapt or recover.”
Further experiments are under way to find out whether the beetles can adapt to heat shocks and to examine how other species, such as butterflies, cope with raised temperatures.
The research is among the first of its type on cold-blooded creatures. “There is a big gap, as most of life on Earth is cold-blooded and it is much more directly affected by temperature variations,” Gage said. “We’ve shown that sperm function is an especially sensitive trait when the environment heats up, and in [species] representing a huge amount of global biodiversity.”
How the heat damages the sperm is not fully understood, though the researchers noticed damage to sperm membranes. It is likely that the DNA in the sperm is also damaged, meaning harm can be passed to offspring. Most warm-blooded male animals protect sperm from excessive heat by having testes outside the body, leaving them several degrees cooler.
Wigby said the understanding of factors that reduced male fertility was poor. “So any studies that add to our understanding of the basic mechanisms underlying variation in male fertility is valuable. Showing that the harm can occur in a heatwave-like scenario is new and important, as is the demonstration of transgenerational effects. However, the applicability to the real world is always an issue for lab studies.”
