comments:
[{u'author': u'Peter Wizard', u'text': u'Many stillwaters are overstocked now with stunted fish populations prevailing. If you want decent specimens then either fish numbers have to be controlled or you have to feed the fish yourself. Best to keep a water in as near natural condition as possible, I think, and that means netting operations every so often to remove excess numbers. I wouldn't rely on a drout to do the job.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542452605000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17731165', u'id': u'122661742', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gadusmorhua', u'text': u'In Ceredigion we had a longer dry spell than southern England, and our spring dried up for the first time in three generations.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542434805000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13286128', u'in_reply_to': u'122559886', u'id': u'122656009', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'1000100101', u'text': u'Well, at least Scotland and Ireland are OK. Certainly wasn't any exceptional weather here in the summer - mainly cool, windy and damp, same as ever.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542420499000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100795284', u'id': u'122654971', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'The droughts around the world are leaving fish high and dry in many places. Birds need water too so if you put out food for them please remember the water to go with it!', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542411353000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16314139', u'id': u'122653313', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PhilGates', u'text': u'I’m sure you are right, but I think that what is most significant about these latest climate change observations from the Met Office is that the frequency of these exceptional weather events, drought and flooding, is increasing to the point where they could become the norm, perhaps much sooner than anyone anticipated. 
Flora and fauna often recover quite quickly from one-off events but when these occur more frequently, there tends to be a shift in the relative abundance of species that are better or worse adapted to the new prevailing conditions. Rare species can become common, because the climate now suits them better, and common species that are now less well adapted can decline. And when species that are worst affected decline, other opportunists take their place – notably invasive species introduced through agriculture or horticulture. This is one of a number of ways in which ecological changes occur.
And so the species composition of landscape changes. Whether the change is for the worse, or is just ‘different’ is an interesting question. Because our flora and fauna are so well documented by naturalists, perhaps more so than in any other country, we are conditioned to think of it with what might be considered a ‘museum curator mindset’, with some golden age, perhaps just prior to the industrial revolution, as the datum point against which everything is measured. But, of course, our countryside and its flora and fauna has changed ever since the retreating glaciers left a landscape of bare rock. The big difference now, compared with previous periods of climate change, is the catastrophic, all pervasive effect of human activity, particularly intensive agriculture, on species abundance. 
It seems to me that, for naturalists in general and perhaps Country Diarists in particular, we live in very interesting times and that observing and documenting the ‘here and now’ might be something that will be valued by future generations. The Guardian Country Diary eye-witness accounts from a century ago, which are reprinted here every Monday, interest many people because they provide a window on a natural world that has sometimes changed almost beyond recognition.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542364380000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the climate now suits them better and common species that are now less well adapted can decline', u'effect': u'rare species can become common'}, {u'cause': u'they provide a window on a natural world that has sometimes changed almost beyond recognition', u'effect': u'which are reprinted here every monday interest many people'}], u'author_id': u'4473185', u'in_reply_to': u'122594739', u'id': u'122622638', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sgiwen', u'text': u'I might add that where we live, nearer the coast, we have only recorded ONE completely rain free week this year! Between 5th and 12th November it was 85 mm. A village near us suffered the flooding for the first time in over 20 years.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542359093000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16412768', u'in_reply_to': u'122615347', u'id': u'122618181', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'indigenousbrit', u'text': u'Great to hear. Look after them :)', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542355650000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13054683', u'in_reply_to': u'122609460', u'id': u'122615646', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'sgiwen', u'text': u'Didn't see those. We went from Penderyn to Brecon', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542355163000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16412768', u'in_reply_to': u'122610111', u'id': u'122615347', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Wet_Coast_BC', u'text': u'I hope it survives. Do all you can to help it.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542330890000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14523044', u'id': u'122610900', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TuwitTuwit', u'text': u'What of the lower two reservoirs?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542328237000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'18111377', u'in_reply_to': u'122559886', u'id': u'122610111', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'woolwich', u'text': u'Near by me ( South country ) there is a small stream that is used by sea trout and salmon to spawn. It dried up completely this summer and my grandson went hunting for the fry but found never a one. Now the rains have come and the little fish are back. Probably fewer in numbers but they are there.This must have happened before over the centuries and nature must have found a way for the fry to survive. We think they bury themselves down deep into the gravel and that there is just enough water present to keep them alive. Anybody else have ideas?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542326439000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3072366', u'id': u'122609460', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'zuftawov943', u'text': u'... about shallow troubles. Excellent report, Mr G. Thanks.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542311835000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11457447', u'in_reply_to': u'122549416', u'id': u'122600785', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'userles', u'text': u'They will skittle back again.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542304330000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13465775', u'id': u'122594739', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'gilstra', u'text': u'Oh, don't worry, you'll have floods again soon enough.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542295518000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3420317', u'id': u'122585342', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Harvestingkarma', u'text': u'The people happy in the sunshine with their picnics and kids in the local lovely park full of trees and birds. Seems as if South Wales has had much more rain than you have, and possibly a shorter dry spell in the summer.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542275523000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16412768', u'id': u'122559886', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'indigenousbrit', u'text': u'Deep thoughts Phil.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542261385000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13054683', u'id': u'122549416', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}]
description: Tunstall valley, Weardale: Streams have become mere trickles and a third of the reservoir is still mud
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Tunstall valley, Weardale: Streams have become mere trickles and a third of the reservoir is still mud
og_fields.og:title: Country diary: the dry summer has left fish dangerously exposed
text:
Six months ago, when I stood on this bridge over Waskerley beck, which flows from the head of the Tunstall valley, the reservoir that it supplies was brimful. A rapid thaw after late heavy snowfall, followed by torrential rain, had left a pair of great-crested grebes piling up water weeds in a desperate attempt to keep their nest site above rising flood water.
Today, after the driest summer I can remember, a third of what was 66 acres of deep water is still mud. The sluggish beck meanders through the sediment towards a shallow lake, its rate of flow akin to replenishing an empty swimming pool using an egg cup. It will take many weeks of heavy rain to recharge the groundwater in the surrounding fells to the point where a refilled reservoir will cascade over the dam wall spillway again.
Tunstall reservoir, built in 1879 to store drinking water, is now relegated to the role of maintaining summer water flow in the River Wear, three miles downstream at Wolsingham. It has been stocked with rainbow trout and all summer they have become concentrated in a shrinking volume of water. I counted 12 fishermen this morning: only one was using a rod and line; six were cormorants and five were herons, taking full advantage of such easy feeding opportunities. The idiom “shooting fish in a barrel” came to mind.
I walked home through Backstone Bank wood, ancient oak woodland on the eastern flank of the reservoir, across a wooden bridge over another stream, where the trickle of water barely disturbed the autumn leaves that spun down into its rocky bed.
The morning’s climate change news had been of a Met Office report describing a pattern of wetter winters and longer, drier summers. The reservoir’s water level has sometimes been low in the past, but it seems likely that this year’s exceptional weather experience will become the new normal. I’ve known this secluded valley for most of my life, with its farms, fellsides, wetlands and woodlands, all interlinked. There is now a sense of urgency in appreciating the here and now, before too much changes too fast.

[{u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'Yes, we are in agreement.
I was in the middle of an inferno, and when the firestorms hit it was like a fiery tornado, with roofs being blown off houses. At that moment fire trucks wouldn't have helped but would have been of assistance half an hour later when some houses were not yet on fire but starting to ignite, and people needed to be transported to hospitals.
A catastrophic fire may need to be treated like a tornado or a bombing raid. While it is possible under these conditions, with much luck, to save a well-built, landscaped and well-prepared house with well-set up and well-protected water supply, I wouldn't risk it again. Having the breathing equipment, which the firefighter in photo has, would have been very useful though. 
Public awareness is crucial. At least the messages are much better than 10 years ago, and more emphasis is put on saving lives. We will have catastrophic fire conditions in the future, more frequently with climate change, and more people now live in the danger zones. Simple.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542349606000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12505139', u'in_reply_to': u'122612785', u'id': u'122613285', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'In Australia we have a unique and world leading system to combat wild fires and we do it at a fraction of the cost of America.

What cannot be challenged is that the conditions in which fires are occurring are changing - humidity is lower, temperatures higher, and vegetation drier so no matter how well equipped and trained our firefighters, every year the challenge to put out fires increases.

For example, but halving their meat intake. Immediately effective.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542339746000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16662131', u'in_reply_to': u'122611689', u'id': u'122612128', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Daniel Barwick', u'text': u'There is a few wrong comments in this post, but I do agree that Climate Change is most likely causing these issues and yes, we will have another Black Saturday. This is Australia and we have always have bad fires and when compared to the early fires in the late 1800/1900’s where half of Victoria was scorched in a day for example, we have not really come close as yet to that level of fire. However, we are packing more people into bushfire risk zones and that’s ok as long as people understand and accept the risk. What is challenging is that evacuating people is not possible on a large scale with fast moving fires and where both of those issues combine and happen late at night issues like California arise. Mandatory evacuations leave residents waiting to be told to leave danger areas. Mandatory evacuations provide little incentive for residents to improve their understanding of fire and mandatory evacuations strip defendable homes of people willing and able to save home. Another point of note is that training our army to fight fire is useless in Australia. Our terrain if totally different than America. Whilst over there you need an army of people digging up hot spots and trails, in Australia on our rocky soils requires little digging and hose work and water bombing is really effective. In Australia we have a totally different fire culture (that we are loosing) where hundreds of thousands of volunteers spring to action like a fire fighter kicking a hornets nest in America and these yellow hornets defend the nest until they can go home. Its unheard of in America forest firefighting as no one would do that dirty and dangerous job for fre. Yet we do and because we keep volunteers in for many many years we do not lose that experience like America where college kids (firefighters) move on after graduation or they move into the city fire brigades. In Australia we have a unique and world leading system to combat wild fires and we do it at a fraction of the cost of America. We should be extremely proud of what we have here and continue to foster this way of life and wild land firefighting.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542339671000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'i', u'effect': u'these issues'}], u'author_id': u'100887913', u'in_reply_to': u'122609447', u'id': u'122612120', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'PLDD', u'text': u'However, don’t the larger aircraft come from Canada and the US and as they are leased during their off season for fires their arrival may be delayed or not happen. 
That could make the difference in terms of loss of buildings for some fires close to urban areas. IIRC the DC10 was instrumental in helping control the recent Holsworthy fire but had returned to the US prior to the more recent South coast fire.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542339597000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3008405', u'in_reply_to': u'122611518', u'id': u'122612111', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'On Black Saturday my neighbour's house burned down, their oak tree didn't.
I also observed how well wattle trees withstood the fire.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542339267000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15518371', u'in_reply_to': u'122611259', u'id': u'122612080', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'Yes, I am being concerned about catastrophic fire danger days. Before Black Saturday, local fire brigades did well, responding relatively quickly to small fires and putting them out. The website worked well, I would hear a fire engine, check the website how far the fire was, and it gave me an unreasonable impression that at other times the website will be updated as efficiently. 
Catastrophic fire conditions meant that Black Saturday was more like a war, and the fire was unstoppable. I am concerned with planning for such days, worrying more about saving lives than houses. 
I wonder whether we shouldn't have specially trained teams of firefighters and medical staff, moved into various bushfire-prone towns when catastrophic fire conditions are forecasted to protect fire refuges and important buildings where people might be sheltering, and to give medical assistance.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542339133000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15518371', u'in_reply_to': u'122611641', u'id': u'122612067', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'samthefox', u'text': u'indeed. 
you don't go building a mound to put your house on in a flood prone area. you don't go building a metal dome if you live near a volcano.
accept the risk, mitigate them as far as possible and save your own lives. that's life, happens all over the world and to think there's some magical solution to everyones worries is fairytale stuff.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542337615000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100627152', u'in_reply_to': u'122603539', u'id': u'122611896', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'samthefox', u'text': u'i don't recognize your name, so you don't live around here. 
therefore, what would you know about the local rfs? 
nothing. 
there are plenty of outfits that have evolved their own toxic culture they seem unable to shake.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542337151000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100627152', u'in_reply_to': u'122611565', u'id': u'122611845', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'HauptmannGurski', u'text': u'No I do not blame Obama for everything. He had to work in a system; they all do. The Obama presidency has awakened me to the fact that it doesn't matter who rules in Washington; the only thing Americans can agree on is enmity and more wars. 
Of course, it also has to do that there were some expectations from the Obama Presidency (affecting us here in Australia, too), hope for a less hostile world, but we got more. And then Trump came and you wonder what exactly has Obama achieved, improved? There is only one thing that he moved into a positive direction, i.e. leaving the cannabis/marijuana issue to the States. 
It's just so silly to ogle a Dem leadership in Washington. Will the ME wars stop? Will there be reconciliation with Russia, China, Iran - or more wars? Obama was truly full of himself and bad judgement. If you are 'the most powerful man on the planet' for 8 years you ought to have a positive legacy. Even his meddling in Britain backfired. I am convinced that some Brits were put off by Obama telling Brits they'd be at the back of the queue, felt insulted, and voted for Brexit because Obama's overbearing way had negative vibes.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542336363000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"obama 's overbearing way had negative vibes", u'effect': u'voted for brexit'}], u'author_id': u'12176263', u'in_reply_to': u'122610832', u'id': u'122611742', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'If I was younger I would consider this myself. At least I would feel like I am doing something truly useful.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542336091000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'122611689', u'id': u'122611700', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'Maybe both countries and others besides should have a recruiting drive for more firefighters. Pay them enough so they don't need to work if the fire season ever ends for part of the year anymore.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542336022000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15758543', u'id': u'122611689', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RJander', u'text': u'Any plans to maybe move somewhere safer Eric? I don't know where that might be though.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542335880000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15758543', u'in_reply_to': u'122602647', u'id': u'122611670', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bearmuchly', u'text': u'As you correctly point out in a catastrophic fire such as Black Saturday or Ash Weds. many of the game rules for firefightinggo out the window.
People need to realise that several days of 35-45 degree temperaturesafter a dry pre-season, coupled by near 0 humidity and > 100km. windscreate an environment where just about everything will burn and the firecan spread and spot virtually as quickly as the winds blow (they also burn faster up hill due to convective wind currents that a large fire will self create)
In these extreme circumstances fire generates its own behaviour and is farless predictable......fuel reduction can help but is far from a guarantee.......nor are 20 meter fire breaks when spots can travel > 20 km. as they did inGippsland and Murrindindee where I was.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542335652000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'convective wind currents that a large fire will self create', u'effect': u'people need to realise that several days of 35 45 degree temperaturesafter windscreate they also burn faster up hill'}], u'author_id': u'14433057', u'in_reply_to': u'122610406', u'id': u'122611641', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Bennetts', u'text': u'Bulls--t. Fire brigade members come in all shapes and sizes. Get used to it. Expect cooperation and that's what you will see. Cleanouts don't work, unless your goal is to have no members at all.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542335142000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14439521', u'in_reply_to': u'122606869', u'id': u'122611565', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bearmuchly', u'text': u'When you have a catastrophic fire such as Ash Weds. or Black Saturday there are simply not sufficient trucks or firefighters regardless of theirfull time or part time status.......we had 36,000 houses directly threatenedand just over 600 trucks.......as you can see it doesn't divide very well !
Whilst there is some deserved criticism of command decisions at majorevents ( every event teaches more) our rural fire services are increasinglycompetent in their command and control and yes, at times there will behard decisions made about prioritising one area/fire front over another inextreme circumstances......fortunately those huge events are still fairlyrare (but no doubt will continue to increase).
As for the old full time/professional VS part time/volunteer argument,it is simply baloney.......yes, professionals are better trained for certainevents (you would hope so !) and more importantly have the neccessaryequipment that smaller brigades do not..but when it comes to grass andbush fires many volunteers have significantly more experience and knowledgethan their urban full time colleagues plus they have equipment better suitedthan any urban brigade. As for house/structure fires, many rural town brigadesare quite well versed (and often equipped) to deal with them........it is the larger structures, especially where chemicals etc. are involved where I'd choosea full timer and their gear every time.
My small rural town brigade turns out for > 40 grass/bush fires annually (andrising) and to 5 house/structure fires........our nearest full time whiz bangequipped brigade is 40 minutes away, we can be there in under 10......if weneed them we will call them.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542334954000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14433057', u'in_reply_to': u'122610834', u'id': u'122611537', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'John Bennetts', u'text': u'I live in a dry-ish part of NSW, subject to currently and frequently dry conditions and long duration fires. 
I have also for approaching 30 years been involved with fire fighting, including air operations.
I suggest that journalist writing articles such as this one obtain and publish advice from recognised fire professionals before publishing. For example, there are many different local and imported aircraft, of all sizes, used in practice, each with advantages and disadvantages. Those borrowed/contracted from overseas do not only come from USA. Canada, for example, provides some.
And it is not all climate change (or not). Housing styles, population, town planning, expectations of the public, fuel change due to introduced species eg Buffel grass in the NT... the list is long. 
Climate change or otherwise is a decades-long process. 
Risk management is a day by day issue.
Let's focus on risk, cost (human, cultural, dollars...) and related and, while considering climate change as a mechanism, choose to include in our deliberations fire history, political, environmental and cultural issues. The result may be more discussion and less argument.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542334777000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'introduced species eg', u'effect': u'the public fuel change'}], u'author_id': u'14439521', u'in_reply_to': u'122603188', u'id': u'122611518', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'I meant "maintain fire trails instead".', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542334456000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15518371', u'in_reply_to': u'122611453', u'id': u'122611471', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'Thanks for your post - very interesting.
I would like to suggest that we could stop logging of old-growth forests, and pay the loggers to maintain fire trucks instead. Vegetation clearance is one of the reasons for climate change.
In my experience it was the neighbours' houses and not the trees that were burning the most violently and emitting the most heat. 
I don't expect fire services to help much other then to provide sufficient warnings, and it would be good if they could defend community fire refuges. 
Are planes more useful than helicopters in catastrophic fire conditions or are visibility and wind so bad that nobody can fly?', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542334357000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15518371', u'in_reply_to': u'122610950', u'id': u'122611453', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bearmuchly', u'text': u'As a 35 year veteran of the CFA in a wide range of districts..........totally agree with everything you say.
As we try to point out to new arrivals in our district........during Ash Weds. Victoria had something like 650 fire trucks, there were approx. 36,000houses threatened......you simply cannot expect a truck to turn up at your place if a major event like that re-occurs, people need to take someresponsibility themselves and if you can't/won't, then leave early andstay safe (don't wait till the last moment)........after pulling multiplevictims out of cars that chose to wait and see what would happenand left too late, I can only repeat.........listen to the warnings andleave early unless you are VERY well prepared.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542333911000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14433057', u'in_reply_to': u'122610950', u'id': u'122611385', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ccf123', u'text': u'We need to go above the Paris accord targets.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542333890000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12294605', u'in_reply_to': u'122602735', u'id': u'122611381', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ccf123', u'text': u'They don't seem to realise it's a poem not a historic scientific document. But what do you expect from uneducated deniers.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542333856000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12294605', u'in_reply_to': u'122604598', u'id': u'122611377', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ccf123', u'text': u'This comment was removed by a moderator because it didn't abide by our
community standards.
Replies may also be deleted. For more detail see our FAQs.', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542333527000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"it did n't abide by our community standards", u'effect': u'this comment was removed by a moderator'}], u'author_id': u'12294605', u'id': u'122611329', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bearmuchly', u'text': u'Small more isolated and bush surrounded communities increasinglyhave custom built shelters available.....we have 3 in my district whereevacuation is difficult due to limited access roads.
Larger rural communities all have fire plans including safe haven gatheringpoints and of course rural householders are all encouraged to have householdplans.....here the problem tends to be the lack of publicity and encouragementto familiarise yourself.......there is still a lot of "it won't happen to me" thinkingespecially for those that recently arrived from the city.
It is like any catastrophy, there is a high level of engagement for months afterwards then it gradually fades.........it is the same with volunteers,sadly, our local recruitment booms after a major event then slowly ceases.
Household shelters are of some use, however our strategy is to havea good warning system and get people to leave well in advance of anypotential event.........it has proven more successfull in the major eventsthat have occurred over the last few decades in this State. It is the lastminute panic departures that seem to add to fatalities, as California hasrecently shown.....the majority of deaths were in cars stuck on the roads ...something that is largely avoidable if people leave early, even if that meansa day or more earlier ! We know what and where the risks are and how thefires will behave (assuming weather reports are accurate, which they increasinglyare).......if a day looks particularly high risk.......leave early.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542333374000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'limited access roads', u'effect': u'is difficult'}], u'author_id': u'14433057', u'in_reply_to': u'122607332', u'id': u'122611304', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Henalltud', u'text': u'The problem about choice of trees, though, is that you need the right climate to grow them. Oaks certainly would be less easily burnt than pines. but ideally you'd want trees in the Laurel or related families with thick leaves and not too much oil content. These will need good rainfall to grow well, and won't survive being burnt.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542332988000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'12401527', u'in_reply_to': u'122610012', u'id': u'122611259', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'AwakenstoEmptiness', u'text': u'Informative post. Appreciated.Do the small fixed wing planes have the same issues as the helicopters?', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542332884000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100031067', u'in_reply_to': u'122610950', u'id': u'122611241', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Bearmuchly', u'text': u'Allow me to support jaronspeculass's comments.
The alleged monstering of the CFA is a furphy.
Yes, the amalgamation of the CFA/MFB has caused some issues in the few stations where volunteers and full timers are co-posted howeverthat amalgamation was well overdue and should have been resolved decadesago........the impact on small rural brigades, that make up the vast bulk of the CFA is bugger all !
What could be contentious is the issue of the UFU's EBA but that is somethingfar removed from the CFA's day to day operations outside the city and largeregional centres and has no impact on volunteers.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542332341000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the amalgamation of the cfa mfb', u'effect': u'some issues'}], u'author_id': u'14433057', u'in_reply_to': u'122603601', u'id': u'122611181', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'The Coalition attacks ABC, forgetting how important ABC is in emergencies, especially now that ABC seems to have learned from their mistakes on Black Saturday, and do not rely solely on information from the stretched emergency services (but also provide info from callers).', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542331954000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15518371', u'in_reply_to': u'122610093', u'id': u'122611116', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'fleafarmer', u'text': u'Firefighters decades ago were hampered by many factors - lack of training, no research into fire behaviour, very little equipment, poor communication, no road access, no fire-fighting planes, few professional firefighters, no fire bans and plenty of people lighting fires in remote areas, burning crop stubble, etc. Of course fires were bigger then.
What cannot be challenged is that the conditions in which fires are occurring are changing - humidity is lower, temperatures higher, and vegetation drier so no matter how well equipped and trained our firefighters, every year the challenge to put out fires increases.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542331925000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100748378', u'in_reply_to': u'122608382', u'id': u'122611111', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'James Lord', u'text': u'I was a professional (paid) public land firefighter in Victoria for 10 years, as well as a volunteer CFA in my local town. I specialised in remote helicopter operations, so I have certain thoughts on how this job should be done.
1) Climate change is real. We burnt one third of the Alpine Ash areas on two separate occasions between 2003 and 2009, including large areas of regen (juvenile regrowth). Ash trees can't survive any fire before 50 years of age, and so thousands of hectares had to be reseeded by humans. To my mind, if this pattern of fire was normal, the Ash species would never have become established in Victoria.
2) Helicopters are extremely expensive to operate, and of very limited use on extreme days. The are often grounded during the worst fire weather, and even when they are allowed to fly, waterbombing is literally like pissing into the wind. However, on medium-sized fires, with moderate winds, they can literally save a $500,000 house (or someone's life) with a single water drop. There's no doubt that each individual helicopter pays for itself each and every summer. However, this cost/benefit heavily relies on good coordination at a statewide level, and doesn't really scale up with more aircraft on call. You could have had 1000 machines waiting at Essendon airport on Black Saturday, but it wouldn't have saved Marysville, in my opinion. 
3) The public need to change their expectations of fire crews. Nobody expects the government to prevent earthquakes or droughts... but somehow fires are meant to be "stoppable". They aren't - when you have a big one get going, the best you can do is buy enough time to move people and assets out of the way. Don't build your home within 50m of any trees. Put water sprays on your roof. Have a plan. Don't complain about drift smoke during autumn burning activities. 
4) Forget about the US - Victoria has already lost its key firefighting partnership: logging crews. In alpine areas, these guys were already on the scene, with trucks and bulldozers and fit men who knew the mountains, and they had a strong incentive to put out fires quickly before they became big. Logging needs to be responsible and environmentally sound, but back in the day most access roads into the national park were maintained by loggers. These are now overgrown, and consequently we can't access remote lightening strikes and put them out while they are small.
5) Ridiculous OHS rules have destroyed our ability to get onto the ground. Most Vic Government firefighting decision makers are now too scared to send people into the forest to fight small fires. We now sit back and wait for them to come out into the open... where they are much bigger, and close to people's houses. We need to back our people, and accept that you can't fight fires wrapped in cotton wool. For all of these reasons, I consider the question of asset sharing between US and Australia as peripheral. There are much more important (and cheaper) ways to improve our capabilities right here on the ground. The social will is lacking. 
Thanks for your time.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542331109000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100887711', u'in_reply_to': u'122604201', u'id': u'122610950', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'GreenExerciseAddict', u'text': u'On Black Saturday, the vast majority of houses that were attempted to be defended were defended by owners (many of whom were injured or died) because that was the policy. Some towns, like Kinglake, didn't even have their fire tracks on the mountain when the fire hit. The tracks were sent to St Andrews because CFA had thought they could stop unstoppable fire. 
It is high time to have fully professional fire-fighting services in this country. Volunteers are not trained in fighting house fires, and given pre-Black-Saturday deaths in fires the captains' number responsibility is to keep their crews safe. This means they will not go into the most dangerous situations. On Black Saturday, the Kilmore fire (the one that destroyed Strathewen, Kinglake, Flowerdale and other towns) started on a farm and went into a pine plantation. Prescribe burns might help to put out a small fire that fire agencies can get to quickly but once conditions are catastrophic, winds blow roofs off houses, you better off not being there, and having a house that can defend itself.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542329205000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15518371', u'in_reply_to': u'122609878', u'id': u'122610406', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Kickthismobout', u'text': u'I was living in Traralgon last nasty bushfires, the tower was the first thing that went, no ABC radio or TV, we had to rely on commercial channels which was a nightmare, people were dying while they did not even mention it in passing, we must be able to just take over any channel or means of communication to achieve blanked coverage during such incidents.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542328168000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15263718', u'in_reply_to': u'122609992', u'id': u'122610093', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Kickthismobout', u'text': u'In a bad fire eucalypts die, they fare better that is true, your point of fire reduction is though an interesting point, where I live we have many large pine plantations, mostly hidden behind rows of native trees.

The firetrails in and around the Great Dividing Range to west of Greater Sydney still assume that bushfires can be stopped at 8-10m clearings. But just a few years ago, a bushfire 'jumped' the Hume motorway (2x2 lanes divided motorway) near Tahmoor. We may need to rethink firebreaks and fuel-load reduction burns, as the temperature climbs and the climate dries out. description: An arrangement that has worked well for decades is at risk of coming unstuck
og_fields.og:description: An arrangement that has worked well for decades is at risk of coming unstuck
og_fields.og:title: Longer fire seasons threaten to disrupt US-Australia firefighting cooperation
text:
Longer bushfire seasons in Australia and the US threaten to disrupt the sharing of vital personnel and equipment between the two countries, fire experts and coordinators have revealed.
At least 50 people have lost their lives in California’s deadliest wildfires, which continue to rage. Fire authorities and scientists say climate change has made the conditions worse.
In July the US requested help from Australia and New Zealand, which sent 188 personnel to help fight the blazes. That group has now returned.
For about 20 years, Australia and the US have exchanged personnel and equipment during major fires. But there are fears that, as climate change drives more severe blazes and lengthens fire seasons, those arrangements could be strained. 
A fleet of aircraft, including six adapted helicopters and two Hercules water bombers, are also shared – spending the Australian winter fighting fires in the northern hemisphere before being contracted to fight bushfires in Australia’s summer months.
“It’s an issue for us,” said Stuart Ellis, the chief executive at the Australasian Fire and Emergency Service Authorities Council – the group responsible for coordinating with other countries to share firefighting personnel and equipment.
The problem had “arisen in discussions between ourselves and the US”, he said. “In the US there’s less and less talk of a ‘fire season’ and more a consideration that fire impacts them all through the year.”
The arrangement to contract and share the specialist aircraft, which supplement a fleet owned by Australian authorities, had “worked well for many years”. “There’s no question [the aircraft] make a very positive contribution [to fighting fires],” Ellis said.
But he said the arrangement “could be challenged in the future and we are considering alternatives – whether that’s using more local aircraft or sourcing others”.
I think there’s no other plausible explanation than climate change
This year’s deployment of 188 Australian and New Zealand firefighters followed a group of 240 who crossed the Pacific in 2017.
Most of the Australian team is made up of “incident management specialists” – staff trained in a common system used to coordinate and deploy firefighting units.
“In California there are about 4,500 firefighters deployed or available and, at the height of the fires in the western US, there were about 29,000,” Ellis said. “Where we can help is that they tend to have large numbers of firefighters but they run out of incident management specialists.”
Ellis has been in the US and Canada during recent deployments and said the intensity of this year’s fires and the conditions that fed them were “unprecedented”.
“I think there’s no other plausible explanation than climate change,” he said. “It’s not up to the fire services to say what the cause of that is, but the issue of climate change is one we are applying our minds to because it can have an impact on our resources.”
Dr Richard Thornton, the chief executive of the Melbourne-based Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre, said there was already an overlap in the times spent fighting major fires in the US and Australia.
“We are now seeing regular fires in the United States – and in California – running into November, and there were fires last year in December that led to mudslides and deaths. In Australia, it appears there’s more fires occurring outside of what we would call the fire season. Clearly then, there’s already an overlap.”
The Bureau of Meteorology says Australia’s bushfire season has lengthened, and increasing temperatures and drier conditions have increased the risk of blazes.
Thornton said the sorts of conditions that led to catastrophic fire events such as the 2009 Black Saturday fires were “becoming more likely due to climate change”.
The lengthening of fire seasons also meant there was less time to carry out controlled burning, he said.
He called the loss of life in the California fires “truly tragic” and said there were important lessons to be learned for other parts of the world, including Australia.
“We have a lot of people living in that rural-urban interface,” he said. “Some people have lived there for a long time and others have moved there, and we see urban planning schemes that open up those areas for new dwellings.
“Then we see very high fuel loads close to those populated areas and changes in demographics, with more vulnerable people there, or getting older there.
“Combined with all that, we see conditions for fires occurring more frequently. There’s an increase in the risk, an increase in the exposure to the risk and all that leads to a challenge that countries need to grapple with.”

description: Turk held for obstructing public highway and has no regrets in taking part in mass civil disobedience
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Turk held for obstructing public highway and has no regrets in taking part in mass civil disobedience
og_fields.og:title: Artist Gavin Turk arrested in London climate change protest
text:
The British artist Gavin Turk has said every member of the public will feel the impact of the climate emergency sooner rather than later, after he was arrested during mass civil disobedience in central London.
Turk, who was among 82 people arrested during a coordinated occupation of five bridges in the capital, said the pressure to force governments to act to reduce climate change was “the new future”.
He was among scores of people arrested for the obstruction of a public highway on Lambeth Bridge on Saturday in a mass protest to force governments to take action on climate change. He was held for several hours and released later the same day.
Turk, one of the generation of young British artists who became art superstars in the mid-90s, said he had no regrets about taking part in one of the biggest acts of mass civil disobedience for decades, organised by activists known as Extinction Rebellion. 
“It seems like everyone is in an odd sense of denial about climate change,” said Turk. “I was in a quandary about what I could do. I felt taking part was a way of putting my name down and doing something for the environment. It was an incredibly peaceful demonstration and I think we put down some kind of marker. The message is really very slow to get through to people, but it will come to us all, we will all have to deal with the impact of this climate emergency.
“I hope this kind of action has caught the public imagination. It is the new future.”
The civil disobedience in London was matched by other demonstrations elsewhere in the UK, including in Cambridge. The organisers, Extinction Rebellion, want to force governments to treat the threats of climate breakdown and extinction as a crisis.
Five bridges in London, Waterloo, Westminster, Lambeth, Southwark and Blackfriars were occupied for several hours. Organisers said between 4,000 to 6,000 people attended the demonstration.
Extinction Rebellion went public with its message at the end of October. Its growth is a sign that it has caught the public imagination and is offering people the chance to make their voices heard about the need to act to stop global warming, said Tiana Jacout, one of the organisers.
“To get 4,000 plus people on the streets after such a short time is extraordinary,” said Jacout. “We are saying we don’t need to sit back and watch the slow car crash of humanity. We can do something about it. That has sparked something in people.”
The Metropolitan Police said 85 people were arrested on Saturday across the demonstration. That figure was later reduced due to duplicating reports made by officers.
In the past two weeks more than 60 people have been arrested for taking part in acts of civil disobedience organised by Extinction Rebellion, ranging from gluing themselves to government buildings to blocking major roads in the capital.
 Extinction Rebellion cites the civil rights movement, suffragettes and Mahatma Gandhi as inspirations for its campaigns.
The group is calling on the government to reduce carbon emissions to zero by 2025 and establish a “citizens’ assembly” to devise an emergency plan of action similar to that seen during the second world war.
Organisers say they also hope the campaign of “respectful disruption” will change the debate around climate breakdown and signal to those in power the present course of action will lead to disaster.
The world’s leading climate change scientists have warned there is only 12 years for global warming to be kept to a maximum of 1.5C, beyond which even half a degree will significantly worsen the risks of drought, floods, extreme heat and poverty for hundreds of millions of people.
The authors of the landmark report by the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change released last month said urgent and unprecedented changes were needed to reach the target.

description: Exclusive: investments in oil, gas and mining companies held indirectly via portfolio fund
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Exclusive: investments in oil, gas and mining companies held indirectly via portfolio fund
og_fields.og:title: National Trust has £30m invested in fossil fuels
text:
The National Trust has invested tens of millions of pounds in oil, gas and mining firms – despite the conservation charity pledging to cut down its own use of fossil fuels and warning about the impact of climate change.
An investigation by the Guardian has found that the trust – which aims to “nurse the environment back to health” – has more than £30m of investments in oil, gas and mining companies, including BP and Shell, held indirectly via a portfolio fund.
The trust has vowed to decrease its own use of fossil fuels across its estates in England, Wales and Northern Ireland in response to climate change, aiming to generate 50% of its energy from renewable sources by 2020.
Hilary McGrady, the director-general of the trust, which has more than five million members and 61,000 volunteers, has previously said: “We are playing our part by ensuring we reduce our dependency on fossil fuels and at every property we are constantly looking at ways to seek out energy efficiencies.”
A 2015 report by the trust warned: “It is abundantly clear to us from across the breadth of places we look after that the impacts of climate change are already increasing, and are a worrying threat to the fragile and venerable places of natural and historic importance that we care for.”
The trust also opposes fracking, not allowing it on its 248,000 hectares of land, “because natural gas is a fossil gas”. However, it has millions of pounds invested through the fund in BP and Shell, both of which have fracking operations. In July, BP invested $10.5bn buying US shale assets from the mining company BHP Billiton.
Fracking, which involves drilling into the earth before a high-pressure water mixture is used to break shale rock and release oil or gas, is highly controversial because of concerns over its environmental impact.
Caroline Lucas, the Green party MP for Brighton Pavilion, has urged the trust to divest from fossil fuels. She said: “It’s disappointing to see a charity so dedicated to protecting our natural heritage undermining its good work with significant support for dirty fossil fuels. We are living through climate breakdown and ecological collapse – every organisation with money to invest must stop funding environmental destruction.
“I’ve been working to persuade parliament to stop investing MPs’ pensions in fossil fuels for years, so I understand this is an uphill battle – but environmental charities should be leading the way. The National Trust must urgently set out a clear path to divesting these funds and supporting firms that make a positive contribution to society instead.”
Mary Creagh, the Labour MP for Wakefield who chairs the environmental audit select committee, said: “Members of the National Trust will be shocked to learn about the scale of the charity’s investments in fossil fuels. My committee has highlighted the financial risks from climate change, and called on large companies to report on their exposure to climate risk.
“National Trust must ‘green check’ its investments, and invest in the low-carbon and sustainable technologies of tomorrow.”
The trust’s 2018 accounts show that it has £166.7m invested in Legal & General Investment Management’s CAF UK Equitrack Fund, up from £164.9m in 2017. As of July, the fund invested 8.89% of its portfolio in Royal Dutch Shell shares and 4.47% in BP.
In addition, the fund has holdings in mining firms including 1.93% of the portfolio in Rio Tinto, 1.53% in Glencore and 1.44% in BHP Billiton. With at least 18.2% of the fund’s portfolio invested in oil, gas and mining firms, it means the trust indirectly invests in them to the tune of £30.3m.
In 2010, BP was responsible for the worst environmental disaster in US history when the Deepwater Horizon oil rig in the Gulf of Mexico exploded, killing 11 people. A US judge ruled that BP was “grossly negligent” in the lead-up to the spill, in which an estimated 4.9m barrels of oil leaked into the Gulf. Earlier this year it was reported that BP was nearing the end of paying out $65bn (£50.6bn) in compensation.
The trust looks after 780 miles of coastline, and more than 500 historic sites including houses, castles, ancient monuments, gardens, parks and nature reserves, as well as the land.
It has an investment pool of £1.3bn, meaning the Legal & General fund accounts for roughly 13% of the total. In 2015, the charity said it was reviewing its investments in fossil fuels.
A National Trust spokesman said: “It’s important to clarify we do not invest in the ‘fossil fuels and mining’ companies, but in the CAF UK Equitrack Fund, which is a UK equity index tracking fund run for charities.
“We adopt a policy of not investing directly in companies which derive more than 10% of their turnover from the extraction of thermal coal or oil from oil sands. We also engage with companies to improve their environmental performance and see our role as one of actively influencing behaviour and driving environmental improvements.”
• The headline on this article was amended on 19 November 2018 to more accurately reflect the story.

description: Norwegian company to use leftovers from fish processing to make biogas to fuel liners
headline: i
og_fields.og:description: Norwegian company to use leftovers from fish processing to make biogas to fuel liners
og_fields.og:title: Dead fish to power cruise ships
text:
Waste fish parts will be used to power ships in a new initiative to use green energy for polluting cruise liners.
The leftovers of fish processed for food and mixed with other organic waste will be used to generate biogas, which will then be liquefied and used in place of fossil fuels by the expedition cruise line Hurtigruten.
Heavy fossil fuels used by ocean-going transport are an increasing problem as they are even more polluting than fuels for land-based vehicles, emitting sulphur and other contaminants. The fuels contribute to air pollution as well as to climate change. Converting vessels to use biogas will cut down on pollutants and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Hurtigruten operates a fleet of 17 ships, and by 2021 aims to have converted at least six of its vessels to use biogas, liquefied natural gas – a fossil fuel, but cleaner than many alternatives – and large battery packs, capable of storing energy produced from renewable sources.
The 125-year-old company, based in Norway, is also banning single-use plastics in an effort to be more environmentally sustainable. It operates cruises in the Arctic and Antarctic, both highly sensitive environments.
Biogas can be generated from most forms of organic waste by speeding up and harnessing the natural decomposition process to capture the methane produced. Organic waste is produced by all food industries but is frequently disposed of in landfill, where it contributes to greenhouse gas emissions as it decomposes.
Shipping has come under increasing scrutiny as many vessels use heavy fuel oil, which is cheap but would be banned on land for its polluting qualities. The daily greenhouse gas emissions from the world’s largest cruise liners can be as great as those of a million cars on the road.
Battery power is also a promising technology for ocean-going transport, but building batteries powerful enough has been a problem to date. Advances in battery manufacture are making it possible to install batteries big enough to last a voyage.
Hurtigruten is currently building three new hybrid-powered cruise ships in Norway, to be delivered in the next three years.
Daniel Skjeldam, the chief executive of Hurtigruten, said: “Norway is a large shipping nation, but fishery and forestry are also large sectors. They create jobs and produce income, but they also produce a lot of waste products. The steady access to high volumes of organic waste gives the Nordic countries a unique position on the biogas market. We are pushing for more innovation, more investment. I believe we have just seen the beginning of what in a few years will be a huge sector.”

From bald-eagle, 1997:
The Australian government appears to have been caught off balance by the fall in the gold price following the announcement on July 3rd that the country's central bank has sold 167 tonnes of gold, two-thirds of the official holdings. 
The price received was around USD332/ounce. Today gold is priced at USD1222/ounce.
Central banks are supposed to safeguard future generations from unknown and unpredictable contingencies. Gold is generally viewed by central banks as a good asset against such long-term dangers.
The RBA has stressed that its current holdings of 80 tonnes 'is consistent with Australia's longer-term requirements' and there will be no further sales. It is not walking away from gold. 
That is small comfort to an industry which has received a shock from such an unexpected quarter - a shock which is likely to do lasting damage to the world gold industry.
Bringing down the debt was the main reason for the sale.
Another dud deal for Australia.
Just like he sold the first tranche of Telstra for around $2/ share.
A few days later the share price rose of $5/share.
Howard, the patriotic Australian. Not.

Methane from natural gas is made into methanol and this is mixed with other chemicals to make four main chemicals: ammonium nitrate, sodium cyanide, methanol and peroxide.
Products and usesChemical:ammonium nitrate ....fertilisers, refrigerants, explosives, soft drinks and medical applications
sodium cyanide .....gold extraction and processing
methanol .....building products, paints and resins, pigments and dyes, carpeting, adhesives, agricultural chemicals, biodiesel and agents for the treatment of sewage and waste water
peroxide cleaning products, paper pulp, mining and food and textile manufacturing.
Ethane is made into polyethylene and ethylene oxide which are components of a variety of everyday items.Chemical Products and uses
 Polyethylene......bags and films for food storage, retailing and wrapping.....agricultural and irrigation piping, water tanks.......films and wrapping for animal fodder and grain storage.......rigid containers for food storage.......industrial reticulation applications in mining and gas production and the commercial use of watergathering lines in the unconventional gas sector
Ethylene oxide polyols for foam insulation for appliances such as refrigerators and freezers, shoe soles, adhesives, automotive applications, textiles, bedding and furniture.glycol for antifreeze, resins and polyester fibresurface wetters for agricultural applications
Natural gas has no real alternative as a feedstock in making the chemicals that are used in the industries described above. They often require gas to be supplied continuously for efficient production processes.
High temperature uses of gas:
Natural gas can heat rapidly and efficiently and it has low emissions compared to other hydrocarbon fuels and grid electricity. That makes it the fuel of choice for industrial applications requiring high temperatures or high-pressure steam.
One key application is in the high-temperature furnaces required to hygienically dispose of medical waste and associated biohazards. These furnaces require consistent and reliable delivery of high temperatures and this is achieved by using gas.
Without cheap and available natural gas all the above industries would close. And move overseas where gas was available.

Secondly, the coal industry subsequently discovered that this cartel arrangement fully in their favour was still not enough to protect them from the rapidly decreasing costs of renewables. 
The current solution: a federal anti-renewables propaganda campaign while simultaneously drafting taxpayer subsidised deals for unviable new coal-fired generators. Expect those deals to be sewn up before the next election. 
As for gas, until Australia finds the political courage to tear up the inequitable export contracts, we can forget about proper access to our own national resource. The irony is that the latest HELE coal plants being designed in China and Japan have emissions as low as gas plants.
BQEND
You evidence for this is what? 
As far as I know the best coal plants currently achieve a thermal efficiency of just under 45% with an emissions intensity > 700 g CO2 /kWh. CCGT gas comes in at about 450 g/kWh. That's quite a difference.
There's little chance of any coal plant producing lower emissions than CCGT gas without CCS and that's another ball game in terms of cost and viability.
 IEA Clean Coal Centre: High Efficiency Low Emissions: The first way forward for clean coal technology
The other problem with coal plants is the high upfront cost - they are capital intensive compared to CCGT gas. That means a couple of things:
1. It will take a long time to pay off the capital cost and a good deal of resistance will be put up to any moves to early retirement.
2. They tend to need to be run at a higher capacity factor than NG plants to b e profitable.
The case for new coal plant is Australia is really weak.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1542703621000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4069809', u'in_reply_to': u'122763431', u'id': u'122765656', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'RobLeighton', u'text': u'I follow energy consumption and energy source mix for several countries.I don't follow Australian politics but I would guess it makes little differencewhich Party's turn it is to govern. description: Energy company says importing LNG will firm up renewable energy projects but critics say gas is already more expensive than clean alternatives
og_fields.og:description: Energy company says importing LNG will firm up renewable energy projects but critics say gas is already more expensive than clean alternatives
og_fields.og:title: Importing gas to replace domestic supply could push emissions up 20%, AGL says
text:
Controversial plans to import liquefied natural gas into Australia to fill a shortfall as domestic gas is exported to Asia would significantly increase greenhouse gas emissions, AGL has conceded.
Energy companies have proposed four LNG import terminals for the east coast to ensure gas supply and ease high prices. The imported natural gas would effectively replace the two-thirds of gas sold overseas from export plants in Queensland.
One of the most advanced is proposed by AGL Energy, which wants to park a floating plant in Victoria’s Western Port Bay and connect it to the state’s gas network via a high-pressure pipeline.
In an email to conservation group Environment Victoria seen by Guardian Australia, AGL said it could lead to a 20% increase in emissions compared with the same amount of gas extracted and used in Australia due to additional production, processing and transport of the LNG. Some of that increase would be counted as part of Australia’s emissions, and some in the country where the gas originated. 
AGL said the project was critical to cutting emissions from the energy system as it would lead to coal plants, with higher emissions, being replaced by new renewable energy projects firmed by flexible gas plants that could be called on when required.
“A marginal increase in the carbon intensity of the gas used to firm up new renewable energy projects does not materially impact the significant carbon savings achieved by replacing retiring coal plants in this way,” AGL senior manager for project engagement, Kelly Parkinson, said.
There’s no scenario where [importing gas is] in the public interest or a good outcome for the environment.
But Environment Victoria chief executive, Mark Wakeham, said the idea Australia needed to import gas to have a clean energy transition was ridiculous and outdated. He said the rise of renewable energy meant the country was already burning eight terawatt hours’ less gas to generate electricity than five years ago. Several coal-fired power plants having closed in that time.
“There’s no doubt companies like AGL might be able to make some money importing gas, but there’s no scenario where that’s in the public interest or a good outcome for the environment,” Wakeham said.
The dispute calls into question the idea that gas should be considered “cleaner” energy, the descriptor used by the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association (Appea), which represents the LNG industry.
In a recent submission to the Climate Change Authority, Appea said emissions from LNG were on average about half those from coal across its full life cycle, which includes extraction, processing, shipping, piping and burning for energy. An accompanying graphic suggested they were 39% lower.
Opponents to gas industry expansion, including Environment Victoria, said further investment in the fossil fuel made little sense on environmental or economic grounds as it was more expensive than genuinely clean alternatives – solar or wind energy backed by batteries or pumped hydroelectricity.
They said Australia could meet current domestic gas needs at electricity plants, for heating and cooking and as a feedstock for some industrial processes from existing developments, if there was a domestic reservation policy that limited the proportion sold to Japan and China.
AGL’s proposal for a floating storage and regasification plant at Crib Point to operate from 2021 is before the Victorian government, which last month said it would have to undergo a full environmental effects inquiry. Some ministers have expressed support for the project.
The company said it would make gas supply more certain, reduce the urgency to open more gas fields and put downward pressure on wholesale prices by increasing competition. 
Analysts at Macquarie Bank disagree on the last point, finding importing LNG would not lower prices in Victoria and NSW due to the additional cost of processing and new infrastructure. But they said it seemed inevitable at least one terminal would be built to meet demand.
The other relatively advanced proposal for an LNG import terminal is by Australian Industrial Energy at Port Kembla. Proposals by ExxonMobil in Gippsland and Venice Energy in Port Adelaide are at an earlier stage.
Australia’s LNG industry has expanded rapidly since 2012 to be the world’s second largest. It is expected its value will reach $48bn and it will be responsible for 7% of national emissions by 2020, effectively wiping out the emissions saved from the renewable energy target. Gas bills on Australia’s east coast have skyrocketed as the export industry sucked up most of the available gas to sell at higher prices on international markets.
Victoria uses 36% of the gas on the east coast, more than any other state. The state government is considering AGL’s proposal to import gas but has blocked further onshore gas exploration and development.
It has a moratorium on conventional onshore gas exploration until 2020 and an outright ban on unconventional gas projects that involve fracking. With the state facing an election on Saturday, premier Daniel Andrews last week pledged to put the fracking ban in the state’s constitution if re-elected.
Most analysts said there was no evidence Victoria has a significant onshore gas resource.

description: IMO ‘susceptible to influence from private interests and certain states’ say campaigners
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: IMO ‘susceptible to influence from private interests and certain states’ say campaigners
og_fields.og:title: UN shipping agency accused of secrecy over maritime pollution
text:
The UN agency responsible for cutting shipping emissions to combat climate change has been accused of operating like a secretive closed shop.
The charity Transparency International has condemned six countries, including the UK and the US, for opposing moves to open the International Maritime Organization to public scrutiny and hampering moves to combat climate change.
The IMO regulates global shipping and is coordinating a ban on high-sulphur shipping fuel by 2020.
The Guardian reported this month that the IMO has allowed what critics call an “emissions cheat” system to be installed onboard ships to dodge the clean fuel regulations. But the system is likely to lead to pollutants being dumped at sea instead of stored in facilities on land, according to critics.
The IMO set up a working group to tackle accusations earlier this year from Transparency International that it is secretive and disproportionately influenced by the private shipping industry and an unequal influence of certain member states.
Transparency International said it was concerned that moves by the UK, the US, the Cook Islands, Marshall Islands, Panama and the United Arab Emirates could hamper reform at the UN agency and damage moves to tackle climate change and clean up the shipping industry.
Last month these countries criticised moves to make the UN agency more transparent. They said “further expansion of access to information” about the agency “could lead to outside influence”, according to Transparency International.
Rueben Lifuka, the vice-chair of Transparency International, said: “Unfortunately the IMO is far too susceptible to disproportionate influence from private interests and certain member states, meaning that there could be obstacles to meeting the targets for emissions reduction set earlier this year.
“The agency needs to move towards a more open and transparent way of operating, with greater opportunities for public scrutiny and civil society engagement. The stakes are too high for the entire planet for the IMO to continue to operate as a closed shop.”
A spokesperson for the IMO said it would decide the terms of reference for the working group on Monday. The working group would then meet and discuss the issues referred to it, reporting back to the IMO council by Friday.
In April 2018, the IMO’s parine environment protection committee set a target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from shipping by at least 50% by 2050 compared with 2008, consistent with the goals of the Paris agreement.
The global shipping fleet is rushing to meet the 2020 IMO deadline to reduce air pollution by forcing vessels to use cleaner fuel with a lower sulphur content of 0.5%, compared with 3.5% as currently used.
The move comes after growing concerns about the health impacts of shipping emissions. A report in Nature this year said 400,000 premature deaths a year are caused by emissions from dirty shipping fuel, which also account for 14m childhood asthma cases per year.

description: Letters: Gwen Harrison explains why she has become a law-breaker and Sue Tytler suggests other ways of saving the world
og_fields.og:description: Letters: Gwen Harrison explains why she has become a law-breaker and Sue Tytler suggests other ways of saving the world
og_fields.og:title: The need to act now to avoid catastrophic climate change | Letters
text:
On Monday last week I was arrested for gluing myself to the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy in London. On Saturday I risked further detention by illegally occupying Lambeth Bridge, along with hundreds of others, as part of Extinction Rebellion’s campaign of mass civil disobedience (Report, 19 November). Why?
Scientists warn that the sixth mass extinction is now under way, that the survival of human civilisation itself is threatened, and that we have only a few short years in which to act. The UN also warns that we have just 12 years to avoid catastrophic climate change. The science is clear – we’re heading for an existential crisis.
Until last week I was an ordinary, law-abiding citizen. I’ve tried to drive change through all the normal channels – making lifestyle changes, lobbying politicians, being active in the Green party, and even standing for election. These things are crucial, and I’ll continue to do them, but they’re no longer enough. I now believe that non-violent direct action and mass civil disobedience are both necessary and urgent. I’ve become a law-breaker. I’ll continue to get arrested and I’ll go to prison if I must.
When my beautiful, innocent little niece grows up, enthralled as she is by the natural world, I can’t face her, knowing that I sat back passively and allowed its destruction. Along with thousands of others I’m now willing to sacrifice my freedom in an attempt to draw attention to this emergency, and to force our government to act immediately and radically.Gwen HarrisonKendal, Cumbria
• Climate change experts are doing all they can to keep our somnolent world leaders supplied with industrial quantities of strong black coffee. As you report, on its current trajectory, the planet will overshoot the 1.5C target set by the IPCC (Russia, Canada and China threaten to warm world by 5C, 17 November).
The common denominator of mass extinctions is rapid change. It’s not the rise in average global temperature that is of concern, or the level of atmospheric carbon dioxide. It’s the rate at which these things are changing, in a sliver of time so infinitesimally small, on a geological timescale, it is virtually unquantifiable.
If scientists’ worst fears are realised, and the 5C-6C barrier is breached, humanity will kickstart a runaway mass extinction event that could dwarf even the “mother of mass extinctions” about at the end of the Permian, 250m years ago, when virtually all life on Earth was snuffed out.
Have you smelt that coffee yet? Good. Now that I have your full attention, read on. There’s still time. Just about. So lobby your MP, sign online petitions calling for climate change action, donate to environmental pressure groups, and take part in protests. Above all, think carefully about which political party will get your vote. We can do this thing, people. We can save the world. What are you waiting for? Why are you still reading this? Let’s roll.Sue TytlerThurston, Suffolk

As it has largely been taught, Economics is neither social nor a science.
Whatever media I look at, it seems that everyone "knows" that the current economic order is the only one possible, as if it has some divine right. Where is there the intellectual open-mindedness to talk about other economic systems, including a profitable humanised one? Economics Departments have brainwashed more than anything else. The Grantham Research Institute, who often produce (some) informative data on decarbonisation etc, recently published a report highlighting which countries are likely to meet their NDCs (Nationally Determined Contributions), in line with the Paris Agreement. 
They found that only 16 countries met these targets.
BQSTART
The study ‘Aligning national and international climate targets’ was released by the Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment and the ESRC Centre for Climate Change Economics and Policy, both at the London School of Economics and Political Science, and the World Resources Institute.
BQEND
Now, the problem is not the report, but the results of the report. Its just another way of obscuring obvious facts - for example; the countries are: Algeria, Canada, Costa Rica, Ethiopia, Guatemala, Indonesia, Japan, FYR Macedonia, Malaysia, Montenegro, Norway, Papua New Guinea, Peru, Samoa, Singapore and Tonga.
So, I can tell you straight away that 40% of petroleum imports to the US come from Canada; and 37% of natural gas imports to the EU come from Norway. So this is a lie; they might be doing other things but the fact that they are major fossil fuel producers does not lend much credibility to the argument. I mean, its like saying Saudia Arabia is one of the 16 countries in the world aligned with the Paris Agreement. Its just not true. 
So I did a quick check, and this what it says:
BQSTART
“Jeremy Grantham wants to have it all. While his investment firm invests in oil companies, he funds climate change groups. 
The Grantham Foundation for the Protection of the Environment was founded in Jeremy Grantham and his wife Hannelore in 1997. Grantham is an investment strategist whose firm owns stock in energy companies including ExxonMobil, BP and Shell."
BQEND
