article_tags: [Climate change, Environment, Climate change, Science, Donald Trump, US news]
description: But many people still don’t agree with the consensus science that shows humans are the dominant cause of climate change
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: But many people still don’t agree with the consensus science that shows humans are the dominant cause of climate change
og_fields.og:title: Even Republicans at odds with Trump's climate posture, poll finds
text:
Americans, including Republicans, are becoming more convinced that climate change is causing extreme weather and sea-level rise, according to a new poll from Monmouth University.
Nearly two-thirds of Republicans, 64%, now think climate change is happening, compared to 49% three years ago. And more of the general population, 78% compared to 70% three years ago, acknowledge climate change.
But many people still don’t agree with the consensus science that shows humans are the dominant cause of climate change. Only 29% of people say climate change is more from human activity than natural changes in the environment or some mix of the two.
Monmouth pollster Patrick Murray said he thinks climate-fueled disasters, including the wildfires in California, “have convinced folks that something is going on”. But Republicans tend to be less likely to acknowledge that humans are causing the problem.
He said the conclusion for American political candidates is that “the worse the effects of climate change become the more likely people are to believe in it, which is not a very good thing if you’re trying to stop it”.
The results come as Donald Trump and his key environment officials have been discounting a multi-agency report laying out the wide-scale and immediate risks climate change poses to the country.
Trump said he doesn’t believe the findings and the top appointees at the environmental protection agency and interior department have questioned the assessment too, saying it focuses on the worst-case scenario. The report investigates what will happen if greenhouse gases from power plants and cars continue to rise through the century in a business-as-usual scenario, but it also warns of serious consequences even if the world manages to rein in pollution sooner.
The administration has also been actively rescinding environment and climate regulations and trying to expand fossil fuel use that causes rising temperatures.
Trump’s position and his efforts are not in line with public opinion, according to the poll. A large majority of Americans support action by the US government to slow climate change. The poll did not, however, ask people about their support of specific strategies that could include increased costs for consumers.

article_tags: [Biodiversity, Conservation, China, United Nations, Extinct wildlife, Climate change, Environment, Science, World news]
description: Delegates at UN biodiversity conference turn to Beijing to avoid point of no return
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: Delegates at UN biodiversity conference turn to Beijing to avoid point of no return
og_fields.og:title: China urged to lead way in efforts to save life on Earth
text:
China must play a leading role if the world is to draw up a new and more effective strategy to halt the collapse of life on Earth, according to senior delegates at the close of this week’s UN biodiversity conference.
With the US absent, Europe distracted and Brazil tilting away from global cooperation, the onus has shifted towards Beijing, the diplomats said after two weeks of slow-moving talks on how to maintain the natural infrastructure on which humanity depends.
China will host the next high-level negotiations, in 2020, which will be the most important in more than 10 years. This is the deadline for nations to agree on fresh global targets for the protection and management of forests, rivers, oceans, pollinators and other wildlife.
Conservationists hope this “new deal for nature and people” becomes as much of a priority as the Paris climate accord and helps to reverse the current wave of extinction, which is at the highest rate the world has seen since the age of the dinosaurs.
Over the coming two years, China should champion the cause of nature as France championed the cause of climate in the run-up to the Paris deal in 2016, urged the diplomats.
“China is very important. It can be a great leader,” said Hesiquio Benítez Díaz, Mexico’s director general of international cooperation, who helped organise the previous global biodiversity conference. “We’re reaching the point of no return for many species. It’s really bad, but people don’t see this issue.”
Rather than leaving biodiversity on the fringes, where it has until now been dealt with mostly by politically weak environment ministers and NGOs, he hoped Beijing would use its clout to ensure the subject was high on the agenda of G8 and G20 summits and to press for participation by heads of state in 2020. They also want the issue to be taken up by communities, companies and individuals.
This message was echoed by the executive secretary of the biodiversity convention. “We tell China that the biodiversity agenda needs a lot of championing,” said Cristiana Paşca Palmer. “They were instrumental in the success of Paris and they can play a very important role.”
Until recently, China’s dire pollution problems and woeful record on wildlife conservation meant it would have been an unlikely champion of nature. However, under President Xi Jinping perceptions have started to shift. The government has promoted the concept of “ecological civilisation”, established hundreds of environmental courts and played a positive role in global climate talks.
At the conference, Beijing sent mixed messages. It initially ignored a proposal to get involved in preparations with Mexico (the previous host) and Egypt (the host this year), and it remained low-key in Sharm el-Sheikh over the past two weeks of talks. “We were very nervous about their silence,” confided one foreign diplomat.
But those familiar with the Chinese delegation said this reflected a difference of approach. Rather than set ambitious public goals, they said the country preferred to set expectations low and work at a higher level behind the scenes. “They are really determined to succeed, but they don’t know how to do it,” said another source.
A shift in pace and priorities is essential. Delegate after delegate in Sharm el-Sheikh warned of risks to food production and human wellbeing from the loss of corals, forests and the 60% loss of biodiversity since 1972.
There was recognition that the current global management plan has been a failure: among the 20 Aichi biodiversity targets, only one – on the creation of protected areas – is measurably close to being met. Highlighting the low priority that even the host government put on nature, a shop near the conference centre was openly selling an illegal lion hide for $1,500 (£1,170).
This convention established a process to draw-up a “Post 2020 Road Map” with more forceful and effective goals. But the political winds are even less favourable than in 2010. Brazil, which played an important role eight years ago, will soon have a far-right government and its diplomats spent much of the time on niggling issues that could have an impact on exploitation of its world-leading biodiversity. At one point the conference spent 35 minutes debating whether to be “concerned” or “deeply concerned” about the impact of climate change.
A row broke out between developing and developed nations over how to share the economic benefits from genetic sequencing information. Tense negotiations were also needed to set new guidelines for gene drive technology, which can be used to eradicate entire species. Governments stopped short of imposing a moratorium, but built in strong precautions by insisting that no research be allowed without risk assessment , risk management and the consent of any communities who might be affected by the release of modified organisms.
Crucially, the delegates struggled to identify what kind of target should be set. There was widespread agreement that biodiversity needed a single measurable headline goal – equivalent to the 1.5-2C (2.7-3.6F) in climate negotiations. But there is, as yet, no single metric that can cover the complex interaction of life on Earth. Instead, discussions centred on setting either zero net loss of natural habitat or a broad goal to “bend the curve”, which means reverse biodiversity loss worldwide through a series of bottom-up national commitments and wider demarcations of nature reserves, protected areas and traditional or indigenous community land.
Pooven Moodley, the executive director of the NGO Natural Justice, said the conference had seen progress in terms of greater recognition of the need for improved environmental rights and more land tenure for indigenous groups. But he said overall the negotiations had failed to take into account the urgency of the crisis. “It does feel like rearranging the deckchairs as the Titanic sinks,” he said.
Frustrations were also expressed by Ruth Davis, the deputy director of global programmes at the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. “I am used to the UN – its ups and downs – but it’s still disorienting listening to hours of wrangling over single words in obscure documents in empty rooms when this is supposed – quite literally – to be about a plan to save life on Earth,” she tweeted.
Despite occasional grumbles, delegates said the situation would be worse without the convention, which at least obliges governments to assess biodiversity and report every four years (with the exception of the US, which is the only nation that does not take part). Protected areas – the one concrete target from 2010 – have expanded substantially in the past eight years. Conservation efforts have also helped to pull a few species including whales and mountain gorillas back from the brink of extinction.
Pasça Palmer, the UN head of biodiversity, said she too wanted more urgency, but she remained optimistic that a deal could be done in 2020. “The best possible outcome would be to have a clear recognition that biodiversity is infrastructure affecting life and development. We have to govern in a holistic way, not just one species. And we need to make it clear in people’s minds that without it, we won’t have a healthy planet.”
China will have its work cut out.
• This article was amended on 3 December 2018 because an earlier version converted absolute temperatures, rather than temperature increases. This has been corrected.

article_tags: [Late-night TV roundup, Stephen Colbert, Culture, TV comedy, Trevor Noah, Comedy, Television, US television, Ivanka Trump, Climate change, Television & radio]
description: Comics discussed the president’s refusal to believe in climate change and Ivanka Trump’s use of a personal email account
headline: N
og_fields.og:description: Comics discussed the president’s refusal to believe in climate change and Ivanka Trump’s use of a personal email account
og_fields.og:title: Trevor Noah: 'Like the climate, Trump's arguments are getting worse'
text:
Late-night hosts discussed the recent Paul Manafort revelations and Donald Trump’s refusal to believe in climate change.
Paul Manafort double flips, Trump spouts some climate change jibberish, and Ivanka gets confronted about her use of private email. pic.twitter.com/eTqSLWaIre
On The Daily Show, Trevor Noah joked that the Russia investigation “is like a sale at a used Honda dealership. It never ends.”
He spoke about Manafort “double-flipping” after agreeing to comply with Robert Mueller and then reportedly reporting back to Trump with the details of what had been happening.
“It’s like when your friend takes a test in the second period then at recess he tells you what to expect when you go in for the test, although I bet even with the answers, Trump could still mess it up,” Noah joked.
After a White House report that warned of extreme effects of climate change, Trump has remained opposed to the findings. “Like the climate, his arguments are getting worse,” he joked.
In a rambling answer Trump claimed that as someone with such high intelligence, he found the report hard to believe especially as water and air were at a record clean. “Clearly the president doesn’t believe in the science and the English,” Noah said.
Ivanka Trump has also been under fire for using a personal account to send White House emails. In an interview with ABC she defended the usage, saying that she wasn’t sending important work emails.
“I actually believe her when she says she wasn’t using her private account for important work emails because in order to have important work emails, you have to do important work,” he said.
He continued: “Her inbox is probably just Goop newsletters and thousands of unopened emails from Eric.”
On The Late Show, Stephen Colbert also spoke about Manafort. “He’s afraid to rat on the Russians because he has a lifelong dream of continuing to live,” he said. “He’s got this bucket list of not ending up in a series of buckets.”
He also referenced the exclusive findings from the Guardian on Manafort’s meeting with Julian Assange. “If this is true then this means the world’s palest man met the world’s shadiest man,” he said.
Colbert continued: “OK, that looks bad but only because it is very bad.”

description: In the fourth part of our series looking at the climate report Trump tried to bury over Thanksgiving, we examine how sea-level rise will reshape the population
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: In the fourth part of our series looking at the climate report Trump tried to bury over Thanksgiving, we examine how sea-level rise will reshape the population
og_fields.og:title: Why rising seas will force coastal residents to move – or spend
text:
The Trump administration published a major report on climate change the day after Thanksgiving. We will explore the key findings each day this week.
Donald Trump doesn’t believe his own government’s major report on climate change – which the administration tried to bury over the Thanksgiving break. It warns that rising temperatures are already harming America and will cause huge damage globally.
US coastal communities are already bearing the brunt of rising seas and more extreme weather made worse by climate change, as was evident with the vicious 2017 hurricane season.
Sea-level rise could reshape the country’s population distribution, resulting in 13.1 million people who might need to migrate by 2100 if the oceans are 6ft higher (which is actually 2ft lower than the most extreme scenario estimated). That will be expensive. Already, the federal government spent $48m to resettle a tribe in Louisiana.
The US is losing more than 80,000 acres of coastal wetlands per year, mostly in the Gulf of Mexico. By 2100, the US is likely to lose an additional 16% of wetlands.
The wetlands are valuable ecosystems that protect humans from storms, reduce erosion from waves, enhance water quality and support fisheries and recreation. They also are sinks for the carbon dioxide from power plants, cars and industry that causes climate change. As they are degraded, they will not be able to soak up as much CO2.
The National Climate Assessment raises tough questions about whether people will retreat, accommodate or protect against harsher storms and disappearing land. Helping people adapt to climate change along the coast is a difficult political proposition, as some property owners can afford to modify their homes or move while others cannot.
Coastal cities – including Boston, New York, Miami, San Francisco, New Orleans and Los Angeles – are already spending to adapt to sea-level rise and more frequent flooding. But the resources they are allocating are not enough to meet future threats, the report notes.

It is scary.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543715493000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'14420517', u'in_reply_to': u'123200700', u'id': u'123220443', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'DavidFTA', u'text': u'Chinese power station construction has been in remote areas so they can shut down older more polluting stations closer to cities. China's already passed peak coal consumption, and both India and China are already installing more new renewables than new coal. This makes financial sense, because new-build renewables have been cheaper per MWh that new-build coal. 
The Good News is, new-build renewables are now cheaper than existing coal in places such as Australia which has old clapped-out coal-burners.
That is, Australia would be deadset stupid to allow new coal mines, becaue they'll be shutting down again before the capital investment is recovered - let alone enough profit made to pay for site remediation. As for Australia's existing coal mines, well they'll be shutting down when their markets cease to exist. 
I would like to think that responsible companies and/or governments will have set aside enough money for all the site remediation that will be required - but such prudence and long-term thinking is beyond the capacities of our kneejerk ruling class.

Sorry but if people are now spending $2000 a year on power and are on struggle street, they need to have a hard look at how they are using it. Essentials such as running a fridge and occasional use of AC is all you need for comfortable life in this country, everything else is a luxury. Personally I have no trouble even contemplating paying twice as much per kWh if it is completely renewable.....household of four here and we get buy on an average of 5 kWh a day......yeh some households use 4 times that..... either pay for it or modify use.Climate change is a silent invader, not immediately threatening as enemy aircraft bombing your area, but in the long term more damaging. That horse has bolted & these young people as well as the majority of Australians know very well what is not being done by the pretend adults in this government.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543623037000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16710744', u'in_reply_to': u'123193663', u'id': u'123196902', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'kkoala26', u'text': u'At some point in your life you might want to try actually learning about something in depth rather than spouting off I’ll informed tribal sound bites. To suggest that the Queensland Premier is ‘grandstanding’ by doing her job during this crisis is revolting.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543622627000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'extreme heat and dry', u'effect': u'walls of fire'}], u'author_id': u'14420517', u'in_reply_to': u'123167358', u'id': u'123196847', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Mathias Rogala-Koczorowski', u'text': u'I attended the Martin Place Strike action to offer humble support from the justly castigated older generation who have been prodigally squandering the birthright of the young, and I have not found such inspiration, encouragement and grounds for hope in anything for many a long year. We are obliged to take heed of them, they will inherit what ravaged remains we have still left them.
As for PM Morrison’s arrogant patronizing lecture for them to stick to their education and leave it to the grown ups, no one believes his disingenuous claim that doing nothing is enough. And those kids are exhibiting everything that one could hope an education could impart, civic engagement, independence of mind and the ability to draw rational conclusions. Not to mention moral values and the willingness to put the good of all before the narrow petty short term self interest of our leaders in politics, culture and society. 
They absolutely get that climate change is real, is happening now, is is critically desperate and will be disastrously worse, to what extent depending on what we do or don’t do bight now.', u'recommendation_count': u'9', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543620906000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17148756', u'id': u'123196557', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'EdwinaCanberra', u'text': u'If we chose, at random, 50 Senators & MPs & 50 of the striking school students, & had all 100 sit a test on climate science design by Australia's top climate scientists, I wonder which group would score higher marks?
I have little doubt the students would beat the pollies hands down.
So who, really, has evidence-based science on their side? And how many pollies would be embarrassed to be beaten by 10 year-olds?
Do not disrespect young Australians. No matter their age, they have as much right as any Australian to demand that governments implement evidence-based policy in their interest & in the national interest.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543620396000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15534320', u'id': u'123196449', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'futurefutures', u'text': u'Sixteen years olds are mature enough to vote. Yes it is, simplistic bullshit. 
So you've decided, in this day of instant information, that anyone under the voting age has no independent thought process, for these kids, this isn't about grubby politics, Its about their future, the one where they clean up after small minded, greedy and selfish conservatives....!!!!', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1543617430000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100867843', u'in_reply_to': u'123177197', u'id': u'123195631', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Fred1', u'text': u'I was in a taxi yesterday and heard some talkback show on the radio.
I can’t really tell the difference between them.
Anyway this presenter started his segment with a patronising address to the students in which he made three claims:
a) climate change is not real;b) carbon emissions are good for the environment;c) there’s nothing we can do about it anyway.
I was left wondering why he said these things.
There’s two possibilities:
a) he’s being paid to say these things; orb) he’s stupid.
I do think it’d be worth someone’s while really digging deep on these denialists to see if there’s a link with the fossil fuel industry.
It’s well known that radio hosts are paid to talk about a new product or show or whatever. Can we get a link that shows these people being truly corrupt?

description: High-school students are told to stay away from political discussion
og_fields.og:description: High-school students are told to stay away from political discussion
og_fields.og:title: I was suspended for protesting the Vietnam war – history is on the side of the climate change student activists | Chips Mackinolty
text:
Just a couple of months shy of 50 years ago, along with other students, I produced an anti-Vietnam war poster that urged high-school students to join the Student Underground Movement.
As my first piece of street art it was hardly earth-shattering but was a tiny part of something that contributed, by May 1970, to a major student strike in which thousands of high-school students in Sydney and Melbourne took to the streets to protest the war in the lead-up to the moratoriums of that year.
It was a distant war insofar as it was in an obscure part of south-east Asia, but one with immediate consequences for those high-school students. If nothing else, some students — or their brothers — faced conscription and potential death on the Mekong Delta or the jungles of Nui Dat; let alone complicity in a colonial war that was leading to the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocent people.
A response of Liberal-Country party governments at the time was to suspend students who participated in anti-Vietnam war activities. Indeed, the then Victorian premier, Henry Bolte, threatened to expel students and prevent them from completing their high-school certificates. I was lucky in New South Wales, only being suspended for two days for daring to display a Vietnam moratorium sticker on my school bag — others were suspended for longer or indeed expelled.
And so the response to recent high-school activism over climate change by the prime minister, Scott Morrison, has an uncanny echo five decades on.
There’s a different set of initials now: LNP. But the message is the same. High-school students should shut up, knuckle down, and stay away from the real world of political discussion – in this case the issue of climate change and campaigns to shift government action/inaction on the issue.
We shouldn’t be listening to young people who nevertheless will have to bear the consequences of climate change – that “listening” is bitterly opposed by our prime minister.
He told parliament they should stay in the classroom rather than thinking about things that “can be dealt with outside of school”.
Really?
“Each day I send my kids to school and I know other members’ kids should also go to school but we do not support our schools being turned into parliaments,” Morrison said in parliament.
“What we want is more learning in schools and less activism in schools.
“We are committed to all of these things [climate change action] but I will tell you what we are also committed to — kids should go to school.”
Learning? Activism? Going to school?
You don’t get it, prime minister. Your government urges young people to take up Stem subjects — yet rejects them out of hand when they take those learnings into life in confronting climate change.
Perhaps it is the politicians that should go back to school and do a bit of learning.
And all power to those high-school students who will be putting their hands up on climate change. History is on your side.
Chips Mackinolty is an Alice Springs-based artist and writer

The conclusion has 4 parts and you "think" the above sentence is a summary of the 4 parts of that conclusion? it does not align with the first part:
BQSTART
This review first confirms that over the past decades to century, atoll islands exhibited no widespread sign of physical destabilization by sea-level rise. The global sample considered in this paper, which includes 30 atolls and 709 islands, reveals that atolls did not lose land area, and that 73.1% of islands were stable in land area, including most settled islands, while 15.5% of islands increased and 11.4% decreased in size. Atoll and island areal stability can therefore be considered as a global trend. Importantly, islands located in ocean regions affected by rapid sea-level rise showed neither contraction nor marked shoreline retreat, which indicates that they may not be affected yet by the presumably negative, that is, erosive, impact of sea-level rise.
BQEND

That paper was a "bummer". The burial of heat in the ocean is of course a gift. But that gift is also acid. 
As I like to remind myself of - the problem with AGW is not that we know the trajectories of things. That we know sensitivity is around 3 degrees give and take. 
The problem is that we continue with our multi generation experiment with a deep understanding of what knowledge we lack. 
If we humans could simulate reality (or just climate) perfectly, we could determine the number of fossil carbon molecules we can burn and be A-OK perfectly. But sadly we do not have perfect knowledge. And the bracketed answers science do give seems to be too scary to watch. 
The scariest thing at present is that the entire world throw dizes with the physics of reality - to protect the "science" of economics and profit. 
It is like falling out of an aircraft and look at the sensors. The sensors all read 1G. Then we reach terminal velocity and celebrate because our speed has stabilized. So there is absolutely nothing to worry about. Because according to myth, someone is going to give us all a parachute just before we have the thoughts of the improbably falling whale, penned by Douglas Adams: 
"I’m quite dizzy with anticipation …
Or is it the wind?
There really is a lot of that now isn’t it?
And wow! Hey! What’s this thing suddenly coming towards me very fast? Very very fast. So big and flat and round, it needs a big wide sounding name like … ow … ound … round … ground! That’s it! That’s a good name – ground!
I wonder if it will be friends with me?
And the rest, after a sudden wet thud, was silence". 
It is worrying that we humans now have decided that "terminal velocity" proves that all is fine - to the point that a skydiver would not keep the spread-eagle position - but instead take a diving arrow position to speed it up a bit. Because if we can speed it up it will "uh.... It may reverse at some time". 
I start to feel more and more like a bowl of Petunia. 
"Oh no, not again".

Maybe because deep down everybody knows what's coming.', u'recommendation_count': u'7', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541116335000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"maybe deep down everybody knows what 's coming", u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'17048054', u'in_reply_to': u'122109996', u'id': u'122111114', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'The rich soil growing corn in Iowa was pushed there from the North during multiple glaciations. 
It isn’t in the North anymore.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541115459000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122110781', u'id': u'122110953', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheRedBadboy', u'text': u'I recently saw a world map indicating the change in climate projected in all regions and I wondered why it is that in the affected areas people continue to plant, farm harvest the same kinds of foodstuffs that are failing rather than doing what would appear to be the sensible thing and change to crops more suited to the new environments. And globally, whilst there would certainly be hardships in the tropics, overall there would be a good deal more usable land available in temperate and tundra regions. We need to adapt, not stick to the old ways until they simply can't be sustained any longer.', u'recommendation_count': u'2', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541114666000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'2902938', u'id': u'122110781', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Reported yesterday: "The world’s oceans have been soaking up far more excess heat in recent decades than scientists realized, suggesting that Earth could be set to warm even faster than predicted in the years ahead, according to new research published Wednesday."
Ocean temperature likely controls Antarctic Ice Sheet mass, according to the glaciologist Richard Alley.
It's -50 degrees C on parts of Antarctica, warm it up to -45 and who cares? But it is at the melting point at the coast where the floating and thinning ice shelves provide less and less friction constraining ice sheet flow.
An increase of just 1 degree C destroyed the ice shelf constraining the flow of the Jakobshavn Isbræ Glacier on Greenland and such an increase is a big insult to an ice shelf almost anywhere on the planet.
The Antarctic Peninsula has lost 8-10 ice shelves over the last 25-30 years. When the Larsen B ice shelf broke up there over a 5 week period in 2002 the glaciers behind sped up by a factor of 6 to 8 and are still flowing at that accelerated rate today because the cork was removed.
If we sped up all of Antarctica’s glaciers by a factor of 6.5 we’d have 4m per century sea level rise, roughly what occurred for four centuries 14,600 years ago.
This is the reality we’ve created for ourselves; a shoreline which will keep moving inland for millennia.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541113851000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the cork was removed', u'effect': u'are still flowing at that accelerated rate today'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'id': u'122110630', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"Always good to read a study in its entirety." It writes after quoting the first two lines of the abstract . . .', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541113583000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122110334', u'id': u'122110574', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Meanwhile, global mean sea level rise continues to accelerate.
Ice sheet mass loss, notice the lines curve downwards indicating acceleration.
http://www.columbia.edu/~mhs119/IceSheet/IceMass.png
At the recent acceleration rate of ice sheet mass loss of around 44 Gt/yr2 (each year an extra 44Gt move into the ocean) we get 78cm of SLR from the ice sheets alone by 2100. Thermal expansion and mountain glaciers add another 20-30cm, bringing us up to around a meter that we are already on pace for.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541113133000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122110334', u'id': u'122110474', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'Any other crazy conspiracy theories you would like to share with us?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541112771000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100526028', u'in_reply_to': u'122099066', u'id': u'122110395', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'xiphoid', u'text': u'"That's why we may need a period of green authoritarianism"No that is the very worst possible thing we could have. To quote James Hansen:
"The first concerns “Big Green,” the large environmental organizations, which have become one of the biggest obstacles to solving the climate problem. After I joined other scientists in requesting the leaders of Big Green to reconsider their adamant opposition to nuclear power, and was rebuffed, I learned from discussions with them the major reason: They feared losing donor support. Money, it seems, is the language they understand. Thus my suggestion: The next time you receive a donation request, doubtless accompanied with a photo of a cuddly bear or the like, toss it in the waste bin and return a note saying that you will consider a donation in the future, if they objectively evaluate the best interests of young people and nature."
"Greens" are a large part of the problem.', u'recommendation_count': u'4', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541112660000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100526028', u'in_reply_to': u'122107945', u'id': u'122110374', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shifty1', u'text': u'Pulling 2 sentences from an "abstract" of a study really does not tell us anything.e.g. the first 2 sentences: 
BQSTART
Over the past decades, atoll islands exhibited no widespread sign of physical destabilizationin the face of sea-level rise. A reanalysis of available data, which cover 30 Pacific and Indian Ocean atolls including 709 islands, reveals that no atoll lost land area and that 88.6% of islands were either stable or increased in area, whileonly 11.4% contracted.
BQEND
Always good to read a study in its entirety.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541112475000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'16743003', u'in_reply_to': u'122110014', u'id': u'122110334', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"to avert calamities that haven't yet happened."
Global warming is already affecting many people, from droughts, floods, increased storms and wildfire.
Wake the fuck up.', u'recommendation_count': u'6', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541112171000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122109996', u'id': u'122110262', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'"Is it so very terrifying to imagine a process of gradual relocation away from certain coastal areas?"
Most of our large cities are coastal. Their loss is unimaginable. "The economic implications of that, and the migrations and the social effects of migrations … the planet could become practically ungovernable" according to NASA's former lead climate scientist.
https://www.independent.co.uk/environment/earth-sea-levels-rising-nasa-climatechange-chief-jim-hansen-global-warming-melting-ice-antarctica-a7841026.html', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541112094000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122109996', u'id': u'122110242', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'ohcomeoffit', u'text': u'... yes, because second- and first-class passengers can't be bothered saving them.', u'recommendation_count': u'5', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541111748000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"yes second- and first class passengers ca n't be bothered saving them", u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'3037029', u'in_reply_to': u'122107862', u'id': u'122110157', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dale69', u'text': u'Didn't they try to buy the country as well?', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541111209000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3150355', u'in_reply_to': u'122099066', u'id': u'122110037', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'dale69', u'text': u'From the article abstractIncreasing human disturbances, especially land reclamation and human structure construction, operated on atoll‐to‐shoreline spatial scales, explaining marked within‐atoll variations in island and shoreline behavior. Collectively, these findings highlight the heterogeneity of atoll situations. 
Any denialist latching onto this one is really showing their ignorance.', u'recommendation_count': u'8', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541111072000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3150355', u'in_reply_to': u'122100788', u'id': u'122110014', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Crow Black', u'text': u'People and civilisations have always moved, the World is littered with abandoned settlements and cities left behind when the seas rose or fell or the local conditions became unfavourable. Is it so very terrifying to imagine a process of gradual relocation away from certain coastal areas? We shall build anew to suit the times just as humanity has always done only far more quickly if necessary. 
The modern Chinese, for example, have pioneered accelerated construction programs that allows them to build a major development from a greenfield site into a habitable city in just a few years. The effects of climate change will be mitigated with technology when the ultimate need arises, there's no point in continually making predictions and expecting humanity to abandon its essential nature in order to avert calamities that haven't yet happened. Those evolved behavioural traits that have led to the kinds of human activity that causes changes to the climate are the same traits that allowed our species to thrive on every continent in every environment, survive an ice-age and multiply more successfully than any large animal that has come before us. We will keep on being human and, sooner or later, might be forced to expend all our energies upon reforming our societies to suit the climate, and even to reforming the climate itself. In this we will ultimately be successful - have some faith in your species, enjoy your short life and try not to obsess about a future that none of us can know nor forestall.', u'recommendation_count': u'1', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541110979000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'the kinds of human activity that causes changes to the climate are the same traits that allowed our species to thrive on every continent in every environment'}, {u'cause': u'that', u'effect': None}], u'author_id': u'17202327', u'in_reply_to': u'122108788', u'id': u'122109996', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Shifty1', u'text': u'From the study which quotes from 3 islands in the Kiribati group with the study period.

indeed:
just because we don't own the earth,is no reasonto poison it.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541093318000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u"just we do n't own the earth", u'effect': u'what we are doing to the planet is genuinely catastrophic bqend indeed is no reasonto poison it'}], u'author_id': u'100821346', u'in_reply_to': u'122098342', u'id': u'122105342', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Erik Frederiksen', u'text': u'Well, so far we’ve seen only 8” of global mean sea level rise and we could see 1-4m over the next hundred years.
Counterintuitively sea level rise is not uniform globally for many reasons such as land subsidence and lift, ocean currents and winds and even the strong gravitational field of the massive ice sheets.
The gravity from the ice sheet pulls the ocean towards it, as it loses mass the ocean relax away, so for example the loss of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet would cause global mean sea level rise of around 3.3m, but over 4m in the North.
Parts of the N Atlantic have seen falling sea levels while parts of the W Pacific have seen 5 times the global average for the last decade which would be a distinct problem were that to continue for those areas.', u'recommendation_count': u'18', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541091370000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'the gravity from the ice sheet', u'effect': u'global mean sea level rise of around 3.3 m'}], u'author_id': u'15131989', u'in_reply_to': u'122100788', u'id': u'122104357', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'NIF473', u'text': u'Following the links provided for the Global Risk Index is a dead-end because they've deleted the 2013 one from their website. description: In the coastal town of Khindan, the catastrophic effect of rising sea levels is all too apparent
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: In the coastal town of Khindan, the catastrophic effect of rising sea levels is all too apparent
og_fields.og:title: 'We feel like hermit crabs': Myanmar's climate dispossessed
text:
On a stiflingly hot morning, Daw Mya Htay rolls up her longyi, a Burmese sarong, ready to wade into the sea.
“The well used to be the centre of our village,” Mya Htay says, grasping the side of a cement water well. But it no longer holds fresh water.
For the people of Khindan, the well is symbolic of their losing battle with the sea.
Ten years ago, the town noticed erosion of the beachfront. Five years later, the well was swallowed by the sea.
“Because of the storm surges, my old house was destroyed. The sand deposits just fell away,” says Mya Htay. Two kilometres of the village coast have been affected by accelerated erosion.
Two weeks ago, the UN jolted the world with the message that we have 12 years to limit climate catastrophe. Its report urged action to cut carbon emissions to avoid the atmosphere warming by a disastrous 3C. In countries such as Myanmar, even a modest rise could be the tipping point for a new conflict over water and a new wave of climate refugees.
Worldwide, Myanmar is the second most vulnerable country to extreme weather events. The effects are widespread: in the dry zone, home to nearly a third of Myanmar’s total population, temperatures are projected to rise by up to 3C after 2040. In the Irrawaddy delta, in the south – where people are still rebuilding after the country’s worst natural disaster, Cyclone Nargis, which displaced 2.4 million people – the mid-level projection for sea-level rise is up to 40cm by 2050.
A sea level rise of roughly 13cm by 2020 may sound less alarming than the rate in the Republic of Kiribati, a group of Pacific islands that at risk of being totally erased this century. But climate consultant Sonia Leonard, who is working in Mon state with environmental organisation Alarm, points out that in low-lying floodplains where more than 140,000 people live, this increase will result in permanently flooded areas and a loss of productive agriculture land.
People in Khindan have had to migrate from their homes several times. They have moved back as far as they can go on vacant land. “Now they’re literally just waiting for their houses to fall into the sea,” says Leonard, who is mapping vulnerable communities likely to be displaced by climate change.
This year more than 150,000 people across Myanmar were displaced by flooding. What was once consistent rainfall has been replaced by a more intense monsoon, causing flash-flooding.
“We feel like hermit crabs, we do not have a place to live,” says Khin Ohn Myint, her voice wavering as she looks at the bones of her house in the sea.
What’s most striking is that this year has been par for the course in terms of abnormal monsoon periods and natural disasters. 
“If this is just a normal year, with a large storm surge that has been slowly intensifying each year, what happens when a big cyclone hits again?” asks Leonard.
In Khindan, the population visible on the streets consists mostly of elderly people and young children. Village elder Aung Shein’s situation is typical: “My children have had to go across the border [into Thailand] to look for work, so we are looking after their children,” he says.
As people lose their land, experience a drop in crop productivity and struggle with declining water availability, many in Myanmar’s rural or coastal areas are migrating to the cities. Outmigration is also high, with more than 4 million Myanmar migrants working in Thailand alone.
The new government has started to provide financial aid of 20,000 kyat (£9.65) for each household affected by natural disasters, but even officials concede this isn’t much for people who lose their houses or land. 
Shashank Mishra of the Myanmar Climate Change Alliance believes access to water could spark conflict in the future. He points to the dry zone, where people have already been forced to leave their homes due to lack of water or an increase in temperature. “The total monsoon period has already decreased from 144 days per year in 1998 to 125 days,” Mishra explains.
The number of extremely hot days is projected to increase from one day a month to between four and 17 by 2041, adds Mishra, which will also cause serious health problems.
Ten years after Cyclone Nargis, some villages have received new cement tanks to hold fresh water, but there remains a pressing need for better adaptation planning.
Leaning over a map of the Irrawaddy delta, field officer Win Naing explains: “We have built two storm shelters here in these central villages, and we are trying to build more mangroves to shelter village coastlines.”
But if another intense cyclone hits – and since the 80s, cyclones in the Bay of Bengal have increased in number, often developing into hurricane-force storms – taking shelter in a multipurpose shelter may not be enough.
One expert who has worked in Bangladesh advocates a “land bank”, for the government to earmark vacant land that can be allocated to future climate-displaced people. Setting aside parcels of land, which vulnerable communities can move, to is a concrete solution in a rights-based approach that aims to prevent land conflict.
Scott Leckie of Displacement Solutions in Australia warns: “In most places in the developing world they [climate migrants] will end up landless, migrating from rural areas and ending up in slums in the cities with severe increased poverty, if there is no assistance.”
U Hla Maung Thein, from the environment and conservation ministry, says the government is trying to work towards the goals set in the Paris agreement. “We have initiated plans such as a fish adaptation project, and for a community forest in Hinthada in the Ayeyarwady division and Chauk in the Magway region.”
Climate activists welcome the government’s pledges, but say implementation must be quicker. 
Back in Khindan, Daw Mya Htay gives her grandson a push on his bike while discussing climate change. She sighs. “It would be convenient if there was no sea level rise,” she says. Then, turning back to her house she shrugs. “But if it does, where will we go?”

If nothing else was going on, there was always the odd crusade to go on in some vain attempt to recapture Jerusalem.', u'recommendation_count': u'3', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541504324000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'3684556', u'in_reply_to': u'122220015', u'id': u'122227085', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'SillyPolly', u'text': u'No economist, or any other scientist, who can only see the world through the lens of socialism can be described as "significant" or "important" as their work is fatally, systemically flawed.
If you make the system all and only about "the poor" - as Stiglitz and his fellow-travellers would - you will inevitably destroy the processes that create the wealth that sustains the poor.
If you believe in a "sharing" society - of work, of income, of wealth - then all that happens is a massive, if not total transfer, of power to those who ordain, who control, the sharing.
There is not a single instance of a socialist country raising up its poor. All the evidence is that such countries lose their energy, their innovators, and decline into life limiting, depressing, monotone social and economic failure.
On the other hand, there is undeniable evidence that the opposite is true, that countries that do not fetter free enterprise do very well for their people.
Claiming to care only about the poor, populism, is a legitimate political path to power but history shows it is without doubt the singularly most destructive. Well then, in those particular instances, the man was wrong.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541497499000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13835441', u'in_reply_to': u'122203837', u'id': u'122222184', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'Hi P_k_Bee. Yes, this is a common view, and it seems, at first glance, to make perfect sense. It does this only if the current assumptions of mainstream economics are accepted as true. 
The very same assumptions which produced the slaughterhouse of the 1900's and the GFC, and if you believe even mainstream economists, the coming crash.
If we replace those assumptions with better ones, perhaps it's not such a zero-sum game after all.
Take wages. Neoliberalism has it that wages are drawn from Capital. Maybe in year one. For a successful business, it's clear that wages are generated by intelligently trained and deployed working-citizens and available in the increased value of work-products. After work is done. Along with a healthy surplus due to division of labour and other productivity multipliers which ultimately underpin the value of the currency. Yet widespread unemployment is a problem.
How about Land. Neoliberalism says Land is Capital(wealth reserved to make more wealth). Land is not Capital, nor is it Money. Capital provides productivity tools to production. Residential uses of land are necessary for production, and non-residential uses of land are necessary for living. Yet monopoly owners of commercial land get all the increases in property values and attendant rents as civilisation progresses.
Clearly Land(aka nature), Wealth(what you want/need), and Money are three entirely different categories of "thing". Neoliberalism conflates them, not to create a more efficient system, or a better world, but to pull the wool over our eyes for the benefit of intergeneration rent-takers, to the catastrophic detriment of the working-citizen and the living world s/he depends on.
As Henry George says in Progress and Poverty, ch17 - "The Problem Explained":
BQSTART
Three things unite in production: land, labor, and capital. Three parties divide the output: landowner, laborer, and capitalist. If the laborer and capitalist get no more as production increases, it is a necessary inference that the landowner takes the gain. 
The facts agree with this inference. Neither wages nor interest keep step with material progress. Yet rising rents and land values invariably accompany advancement. Indeed, they are the mark of progress! Increasing rent explains why wages and interest do not increase. The same cause that gives more to the land owner also denies it to the laborer and capitalist.
BQEND
By muddling up the very language of production, Neoliberalism has made it difficult to think about economics without arriving at the conclusion that there are just too many people. And that's scary. It's also wrong. By misdirecting our attention from the deeper underlying cause of our problems, a more constructive treatment is forestalled. We can still fix this.
The answer is to understand precisely how economics was derailed from economic democracy to extractive, growth-addicted madness, how your "civilisation-dividend" was stolen from you well before your birth, and the simple remedies required to restore it. In the process inverting the wealth pyramid to value nature as the source of all usable wealth and the working-citizen as its creator:
~ How Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers Corrupted Economics, Dierdre Kent 2016.The Corruption - detailsWhat Money is: Seven Deadly Innocent Frauds of Economic Policy, Mosler 2010 P1.What Wealth is: Progress and Poverty, Henry George 1879, esp intro, ch3, ch17.How we got to Now: The Corruption of Economics, Mason Gaffney 1994 p 29-44. Excellent Prologue by Fred Harrison: Who's Afraid of Henry George?
For sincere and willing truth-seekers, this short list cannot fail to deeply reward even a cursory treatment.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541559939000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'division of labour and other productivity multipliers which ultimately underpin the value of the currency', u'effect': u'a healthy surplus'}], u'author_id': u'16294933', u'in_reply_to': u'122182725', u'id': u'122257215', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'BuzzBloodOhio space', u'text': u'Appropriate checks and balances? But thats why liberal style democracies should be encouraged as opposed to socialist ones.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541558189000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'17722198', u'in_reply_to': u'122255161', u'id': u'122256799', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushers11', u'text': u'No, it was about justice. Look, lets face it "social justice" is a misnomer, or a contradiction in terms, or a bit of an oxymoron. Justice is singular, about the way we treat individuals. Justice cannot be social because what is good for one person may well be very bad for another. Justice cannot be meted out to a group.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541497367000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'what is good for one person may well be very bad for another', u'effect': u'justice can not be social'}], u'author_id': u'13835441', u'in_reply_to': u'122203837', u'id': u'122222088', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushers11', u'text': u'Corporations lobby government and get things done in their favour. But at the end of the day, they do not "own" the government. After all, government is still the one with all the guns. They are the ones with real power. Just look at any country that goes socialist. Like Venezuela did in the 1990s till now. They (the government) took control of the oil producing. They used their monopoly on force to kick out the private company. If you don't think the US government could do the same thing at any time to any business, you are living in dream land.
The way we can stop this corporatisation of the economy is to stop the government from having any power or say in the economy. A complete separation of economy and State, like we have with Church and State. If the government could not influence things and tilt the game in favour of one player or another, the corporations would have no incentive to lobby and try and bribe the politicians.', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541496789000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'13835441', u'in_reply_to': u'122192288', u'id': u'122221749', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Matt Quinn', u'text': u'+100 Great comment. The new economics will reverse the importance pyramid to reflect actual physical dependencies and time-scaled value through existing mechanisms, but running the new program. As the source of all wealth, the new economics places the living world at the top of the pyramid and a premium on use of natural opportunities. 
As the harvesters and shapers of wealth, working-citizens will be relieved of all tax burdens and those who can sustainably employ the most productive power from the least land will entirely pay for civilisation through an annual levy on the value of natural opportunities. Those who want work shall have it, and those who want to do other things shall do that too.
The entire incentive structure will be reversed, with vast areas of land returned to public ownership as do-nothing rentiers go belly-up, leaving previously locked-up land and massive revenues to fund the transformation of civilisation into what we know must be possible: Humans devising new ways of thinking, living, doing in harmony with the living world which inspires us to do anything in the first place...
Some chicken-soup for the soul, courtesy of 4 years of patiently searching for the radioactive splinter lodged deep in the heart of western "civilisation". It's economics, of course, and the entire 20th century was a wrong turn, signposted in blood. 
As an engineer trained in the social sciences I was expecting mathematics and legal-like discourse, not an intergenerational murder-mystery. But the specifics are there, if you have the time and patience to read about exactly how it was done, precisley and in sordid detail how yours and everyone you knows' "civilisation-dividends" were stolen, well before your births, and by extension, the Earths. And how it can be restored.
~ How Land Barons, Industrialists and Bankers Corrupted Economics, Dierdre Kent 2016.The Corruption - detailsWhat Money is: Seven Deadly Innocent Frauds of Economic Policy, Mosler 2010 P1.What Wealth is: Progress and Poverty, Henry George 1879, esp intro, ch3, 17.How we got to Now: The Corruption of Economics, Mason Gaffney 1994 p 29-44. And "inherent dynamic that leads to inequality".', u'recommendation_count': u'0', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541554794000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'that', u'effect': u'inequality'}], u'author_id': u'100026433', u'in_reply_to': u'122256017', u'id': u'122256060', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Pushers11', u'text': u'BQSTART
"The fact that I have a right to X does not, in itself, guarantee that I have a right to defend X"
BQEND
No, of course it does. If I have a right to X, I do have a right to defend it. That are utterly tied up together. If I cannot defend my life, I don't really have a right to it, as anyone could potentially take it away from me without any opposition at all. Or its like saying I have a right to free speech but as soon as someone tells me to shut up, I must.
BQSTART
"There is, for example, no inconsistency at all in saying that everyone has the right to free medical care whilst denying that anyone has the right to threaten a doctor with a gun if they refuse to provide that healthcare."
BQEND
I am afraid this is totally wrong. It is totally inconsistent. If you are saying that everyone has a right to free medical care, then you are precisely saying that someone does indeed have the right to threaten a doctor with a gun for refusing to provide it. To get to the real heart of the matter, lets boil it down to a situation where it is just you, your significant other and one doctor on a desert island - wider society does not exist. If your wife gets sick and free healthcare is a right, you would be well within your rights to threaten the life of the doctor with violence if he or she wanted to refuse treatment. Henry George explodes the land scam his bestselling Progress and Poverty (ch 17 - "The Problem Explained"):
BQSTART
All wealth is the union of land, labor and capital. If the Laborer and capitalist get no more as production increases, it is a necessary inference that the landowner takes the gain.
BQENDGeorge
gravely threatened privileged global power elites(Fred Harrison), so they erased him from academic history.
In the process they emasculated the discipline of economics, stripped dignity from labour and set in motion a world-destroying doctrine. Neo-Classical Economics(aka neoliberalism) was born(Mason Gaffney).
Progress and Poverty remains the only book in history to outsell the Bible, which it did for twenty consecutive years, yet few social justice advocates have heard of it, let alone read it nor the history of its suppression for the benefit of rent-takers, and to the catastrophic detriment of the working citizen and the living world on which s/he depends. 
Einstein marveled over his insights, and used Georges methods of thought-experiment and powerful inductive reasoning to discover relativity, twenty years later. If Einstein had been so effectively silenced, relativity would still await rediscovery...

description: In the lead-up to his Australian visit, the renowned economist warns of the triple threat of rising inequality, the undermining of democracy and climate change
headline: l
og_fields.og:description: In the lead-up to his Australian visit, the renowned economist warns of the triple threat of rising inequality, the undermining of democracy and climate change
og_fields.og:title: Joseph Stiglitz: 'America should be a warning to other countries'
text:
It’s a stark message from a Nobel-prize winning economist.
“We were a very different country 40 years ago,” he says. “The downhill slide has been pretty fast. America, I think, should be an important warning to other countries not to take for granted their institutions. I worry that things in the United States could get much worse.”
Joseph Stiglitz is coming to Australia next week. The renowned economist and Columbia University professor has been awarded the 2018 Sydney peace prize for leading one of the defining public policy discussions of our age – the crisis caused by economic inequality.
Stiglitz is credited with pioneering the concept of the “1 per cent”, the idea that the upper 1% of Americans have accumulated so much political power and wealth in recent decades – through voter suppression, gerrymandering, and the corrupting influence of money – that the country’s economy has suffered, and its democracy has been undermined.
In 2011, barely two years into Barack Obama’s first presidential term, he warned the political upheavals then roiling countries including Egypt, Tunisia, Libya, Yemen and Bahrain could one day be visited upon the US, but in an American way. Later that year, the Occupy Wall Street protest emerged in Manhattan’s financial district.
Most Americans want a higher minimum wage, they want gun control, they want access to healthcare … yet our democracy can’t deliver it
His 2012 bestselling book The Price of Inequality explained in detail how America had been growing apart, at an increasingly rapid rate. He argued forcefully that the severe inequality in the US was a choice of the country’s leaders: a consequence of their policies, laws and regulations.
This month he plotted in Scientific American how inequality had worsened so much over the last 40 years that US democracy was imperilled.
“Whereas the income share of the top 0.1% has more than quadrupled and that of the top 1% has almost doubled, that of the bottom 90% has declined,” he wrote.
“Wages at the bottom, adjusted for inflation, are about the same as they were some 60 years ago. Wealth is even less equally distributed, with just three Americans having as much as the bottom 50%.”
“As more of our citizens come to understand why the fruits of economic progress have been so unequally shared, there is a real danger that they will become open to a demagogue blaming the country’s problems on others and making false promises of rectifying ‘a rigged system’.
“We are already experiencing a foretaste of what might happen. It could get much worse.”
Stiglitz tells Guardian Australia, in the lead-up to his trip to Australia, that this country has a lot to learn from America.
“One of the reasons I wrote [The Price of Inequality] is almost as a warning to other countries,” he says.
“Some of the forces attacking what I would call the social order … those who are shortsighted and in the 1%, know that what they want is contrary to what would evolve in a functioning democracy.
“Most Americans want a higher minimum wage, they want gun control, they want access to healthcare, they want stronger financial regulation – the polling on some of these issues is, you know, 75% or more – and yet our democracy can’t deliver it.
“Those on the other side have to undermine democracy if they’re going to thwart the will of such a large majority, so they undermine it by disenfranchisement and disempowerment.”
Stiglitz says the vision of policymakers in the aftermath of the second world war was to draw together a community that had fought together, to help society become more equal. In the 1960s that was reinforced with demands for racial and social and gender justice, to break down further the forces that had long-divided society.
“It was a continuation if you looked at it in a grand historical [perspective] where we’d gotten rid of feudalism and hereditary privilege and we were moving step by step to a greater system of social justice,” he says. “That was our vision, with the civil rights movement.”
The magnitude of the dysfunction [on climate change] is unbelievable
But the election of Donald Trump as president, and a Republican push to further undermine economic equality, mean the old social contract is being further undermined.
“Now we have Trump – a misogynist, a racist, a bigot – as president and openly espousing these things, and we have the majority of the Republican party voting for a tax bill that increases inequality and leads more people to have no insurance coverage. It’s further undermining the social contract and [the old] vision.”
Stiglitz says he plans to talk about all of these things in Australia, including the problem of climate change – which he says presents the strongest critique of the capitalist system.
“It reminds one of Jared Diamond’s story of collapse on Easter Island where they cut down the last tree and there they were, unable to paddle to any other island and they’d destroyed their future,” he says.
“We’re doing the same. The magnitude of the dysfunction is unbelievable. And what’s remarkable about it is, some of the work I’ve done has shown the cost to our society of dealing with this is minuscule, at most 2% of GDP, whereas the cost of not dealing with it could be horrendous.”
He says any view of a well-managed society would be “why not deal with the threat of climate change?”
“Particularly because the way you’d do it would actually stimulate the economy.”
Prof Joseph Stiglitz will be in Australia to receive the Sydney peace prize. He will be awarded the prize at the City of Sydney peace prize lecture on 15 November, and speak at the National Press Club in Canberra on 14 November and at the Athenaeum Theatre in Melbourne on 19 November

It struck me as a shame that they don't impose such rules on their politics reporters.', u'recommendation_count': u'25', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541596914000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'11735633', u'id': u'122272324', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'My_Full_Name', u'text': u'Oh George, I'm sorry mate. 
David Attenborough is a personal hero of mine but I can't help agreeing with what you have written. I cannot help but feel that the response BTL to any article you could write about the environment and the destruction of the natural world would be met with the same sort of negativity as is seen here, even if this is the Guardian.
I've thought for a long time that both that the natural world is for the most part done for, with the human race not far behind. It's such a shame.
Every so often you see a new scientific study showing the incredible decline in species around the world due to the impact of man, and even when these studies receive the attention they should in the media, it seems to barely cause a ripple with people as a whole. You'd think the news that humanity has wiped out 60% of animal species worldwide since 1970 would light a fire under enough people for some sort of change to made, but in fact it's pretty much forgotten within a week.
Let's be honest, we're not there as a species yet. People are to selfish and self involved to care about each other, never mind some wildlife on the other side of the world. We will willingly oversee our destruction of the natural world while ignorantly shrugging our shoulders asking "well, what could we have done about it", conveniently forgetting the many, many warnings we have had. We're well past the point of no return to reverse any damage significantly. People want their life to get better and more convenient, they will not take a step back and inconvenience themselves so the natural world can recover even slightly, never mind what is required for it to actually flourish.
Myself and my wife use our holidays to travel the UK seeing as much of the natural world has to offer, it started due to a mutual love of the natural world, but has now turned into a race against time to see it before disappears altogether.
Even though I personally think the destruction of the natural world is a inevitability, I'm happy that you're here to keep fighting the good fight.
Keep that thick skin and maybe one day you may start getting through some of those thick skulls.', u'recommendation_count': u'57', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541597159000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'it', u'effect': u'a ripple with people as a whole'}, {u'cause': u'the impact of man', u'effect': u'showing the incredible decline in species around the world'}, {u'cause': u'a mutual love of the natural world', u'effect': u'myself and my wife use our holidays to travel the uk seeing as much of the natural world has to offer it started but has now turned into a race against time to see it before disappears altogether'}], u'author_id': u'12579008', u'id': u'122272527', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'2thirdsoflightspeed', u'text': u'Small steps are no longer enough to stop AGW getting worse.', u'recommendation_count': u'14', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541597151000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'100062996', u'in_reply_to': u'122272195', u'id': u'122272518', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'Djangorules', u'text': u'What he said was that they already had an Irish announcer on BBC2. Some on the left will never forgive him for this because (for some reason that I have never understood) this is something that must never be said.', u'recommendation_count': u'30', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541596395000}, u'causal_relations': [{u'cause': u'for some reason that i have never understood this is something that must never be said', u'effect': u'some on the left will never forgive him for this'}], u'author_id': u'2692535', u'in_reply_to': u'122270435', u'id': u'122271936', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'TheOLEDman', u'text': u'My disagreement with this article is that there is a deep psychological point that means that Attenborough is right in this. When people become emotionally attached to ideas then they become far more resistant to change, especially when the counterarguments are framed in an emotional manner. Because climate change has become so intensely politicised now, people tend to follow the tribal habits of just agreeing with whatever their chosen political party state about the issue, rather than dealing with them independently. We see the same behaviour in many spheres of life, from politics and healthcare to anti-vaccine movements. A soft approach is often beneficial. An example right now that I can think of is Bernie Sanders, when he has sat down with people and just talked over healthcare, demonstrating that single payer is actually better than the current US system, and convinced people that were previously hostile to the idea.
You have to get people talking - especially the people who disagree with you. Pointing out extremes and loudly declaring how wrong someone else is rarely does that.', u'recommendation_count': u'21', u'time_stamp': {u'$date': 1541597106000}, u'causal_relations': None, u'author_id': u'4669518', u'id': u'122272475', u'schema_org_type': u'http://schema.org/Comment'}, {u'author': u'discuz', u'text': u'The progress Attenborough believes in and has been instrumental in pivots around economic growth. Any way, let me tell you what I saw in Payangan yesterday. While there I saw a little girl carrying a small cage with two finches it it. The cage was not much bigger than the size of a standard can of beans.
One finch has been dyed yellow, the other pink presumably to make them more 'fun' (?) The two finches were crammed in and clearly very agitated indeed.
At one point the darling child, unsupervised, put the cage on the floor and began kicking it along the ground with the two birds in it. This is the kind of mindless cruelty done to animals you see done everyday in Bali.
I stepped in to stop the obvious cruelty to the birds. I gave them some seed and water but they were too agitated to have any interest in it. I couldn't release the birds because the parents would been mad at me.
